STAYS AND BAIL:
Stays:
Application for stay denied without prejudice to appli-
cation for stay to three-judge District Court
(A-356)
Application for stay denied. Justice Douglas would
grant stay believing that Ohio anti-riot statutes, Ohio
Code §§ 2923.52 to .54 on their face seem overly broad
and prima facie infringe on freedom of expression
protected by First Amendment (A-507) --
Application for stay of execution of sentence for civil
contempt granted pending further order of this
Court (A-926) –
Bail:
Application for release on bail denied without preju-
dice to renewed application to the District Court
(71-1255)

arguments completed April 20, 1972-

Final order (June 29, 1972) ---

MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1971
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
1
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce that the 1971 Term of the Supreme
Court of the United States is now convened."
The Chief Justice said:
"It is a sad duty for us to take note today, on opening the October
1971 Term of Court, of the absence from this Bench for the first time
in 34 years, of our beloved colleague the late Justice Hugo Black. His
tenure spanned that of 5 of the 15 Chief Justices who have presided
here since the Constitution was adopted and his departure is a pro-
found loss to each of us personally and to the Court.
"Much has been and much more will be said and written of the life
and work of Mr. Justice Black. His public service in the Army in
World War I, in the State of Alabama, in the United States Senate,
and on this Court covered more than 50 of the 85 years of a life rich
in accomplishment.
"In time, I believe, one thing will stand out above all in his work
and in his thinking. Throughout his entire life he never wavered in
his unbounded faith in the people and in the political processes of a
free people under the American Constitution. He loved this Court
as an institution, and contributed mightily to its work, to its strength,
and to its future. He revered the Constitution; he had enormous
respect for the Presidency and for the Congress, but above all else,
he believed in the people.
"In a period when institutions are under attack and when people
are having doubts about their capacity to govern themselves, this
should give heart to all, for Hugo Black had no doubt whatever about
the ability of an informed and free people to govern their own destinies.
"We will miss his wise counsel, his rare spirit, his vigor, his sparkle,
and the warmth of his comradeship.
"In the near future a date will be fixed for presentation in this Court
of appropriate memorials to him."
480-278-71-1

MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1971
2
The Chief Justice said:
"It is with deep regret that we take note today of the retirement of
our beloved colleague, Mr. Justice Harlan, who served on this Court.
since March 28, 1955, after prior service on the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit.
“Before going on the Bench, Mr. Justice Harlan combined a bril-
liant career as a lawyer with significant positions of high public re-
sponsibility, including a distinguished military career in the European
theater in World War II. Ill health led Mr. Justice Harlan to submit
to retirement when his high sense of duty persuaded him he could not
continue to carry out his obligations to the Court. The volumes of the
U.S. Reports from 1955 through the most recent Term attest to his
prolific and erudite contributions to the work of the Court.
"I speak for the whole Court, and the Bar as well, in expressing
heartfelt wishes for Justice Harlan's restoration to health."
ORDER
On September 24, 1971, during the summer recess, the Chief Justice
entered an order pursuant to Title 28 U.S.C. Sec. 42 temporarily
assigning Mr. Justice Marshall to the Second Circuit as Circuit Justice.
ADMISSION OF ATTORNEYS DURING THE SUMMER RECESS
The following attorneys were admitted to the Bar of the Court by
action of single Justices during the summer recess, pursuant to the
Order of the Court entered on the twenty-fourth day of May, 1971:

Adjourned until Tuesday, October 12, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
The day call for Tuesday October 12, 1971, will be as follows: Nos.
70–29, 70–58, 70–77, 70–90, and 70–63 (and 70–65).

JOURNAL FOR TUESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1971
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
53
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 70–127. Cecil Hicks, District Attorney, County of Orange,
California, et al., appellants, v. Pleasure House, Inc., et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Central District of
California. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Opinion
per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-111. William Wall et al., appellants, v. California. Appeal
from the Appellate Department of the Superior Court of California,
County of Los Angeles. The appeal is dismissed for want of a properly
presented federal question.
No. 70-201. Philip J. Levin and Bridgewater Leasing Corp., ap-
pellants, v. Township Committee of the Township of Bridgewater et
al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 70–226. Maryland Community Developers, Inc., appellant, v.
State Roads Commission of Maryland. Appeal from the Court of Ap-
peals of Maryland. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 70-296. Shirley M. Spellerberg, appellants, v. Tom Adams,
etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 70-331. Second United Presbyterian Church of Johnstown,
appellant, v. Presbytery of Albany. Appeal from the Court of Appeals
of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 70-5140. Bernice W. Cole, appellant, v. Salvatore S. Nigro,
Judge, etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Missouri. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
480-278-71-8

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1971
54
No. 71-31. Kinney Car Corporation et al., appellants, v. City of
New York et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-59. Gerald R. Hershberger et ux., appellants, v. City of
Troy et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-193. Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad
Company, appellant, v. Washington. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Washington. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question.
No. 70-133. Rudolph Strasbourg, appellant, v. California. Appeal
from the Appellate Department of the Superior Court of California,
County of Los Angeles. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 70-214. William Pinson, etc., appellant, v. California. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be
noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 71-18. Elva Anne Pacheco, appellant, v. Ferdie Pacheco. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the
opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set for oral
argument.
No. 71-197. Joseph Rogoff, etc., appellant, v. Arvid Anderson, as
Director of the Office of Collective Bargaining of the City of New
York, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall are of the opinion that
probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 71-5023. Arthur Haynes and Helidor Martinez, appellants, v.
New York. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Brennan is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should
be noted and case set for oral argument.

certiorari is denied.

ministrator of the Oregon Public Welfare Division, appellant, v.

leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The motion of Harold
O. Swank et al., for leave to intervene and to adopt the jurisdictional
statement is denied. Judgment affirmed.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-114. Cecil Hicks, District Attorney of the County of
Orange, State of California, petitioner, v. Grove Press, Inc. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration
in light of Perez v. Ledesma, 401 U.S. 82. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70–122. Herbert Edward Burgin, petitioner, v. South Caro-
lina. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South
Carolina. Petition for writ of certiorari granted and judgment re-
versed. Redrup v. New York, 386 U.S. 767. The Chief Justice and Mr.
Justice Blackmun dissent.
No. 70-164. Police Jury of the Parish of Vermilion, petitioner, v.
Alton Hebert. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court
of Louisiana. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
reversed. Cipriano v. City of Houma, 395 U.S. 701; City of Phoenix v.
Kolodziejski, 399 U.S. 204 and Stewart v. Parish School Board of the
Parish of St. Charles, 400 U.S. 884.
No. 70-5078. John Latham, petitioner, v. John J. Tynan, Com-
missioner of Motor Vehicles of Connecticut. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
of Bell v. Burson, 402 U.S. 535.

No. 70-5112. Willie Mae Weber, petitioner, v. Aetna Casualty &
Surety Company et al. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis

No. 70-5122. Dennis Stephen Duncan, petitioner, v. Tennessee.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Middle Division,

No. 70-5388. Otis Loper, petitioner, v. George J. Beto, Director,
Texas Department of Corrections. Motion for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United.
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted limited to Ques-
tion 1 presented by the petition which reads as follows:
"1. Does the use of prior, void convictions for impeachment pur-
poses deprive a criminal defendant of due process of law where their
use might well have influenced the outcome of the case?"
No. 71–123. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Burns
International Security Services, Inc., et al.; and
No. 71-198. Burns International Security Services, Inc., peti-
tioner, v. National Labor Relations Board et al. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
granted in No. 71-123. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted in No. 71–198,
limited to Question 2 presented by the petition which reads as follows:
"2. In such a proceeding, may a sub-contractor who is awarded a
contract to provide services at a facility be held to be a successor of
the previous sub-contractor and required to bargain with the union
representing the previous sub-contractor's employees, where: (a) there
is a total absence of dealings between the two sub-contractors; (b) the
previous sub-contractor's performance at the facility constitutes a
small portion of its total business, the balance of which was not af-
fected by the change of sub-contractors; (c) the performance of the
contract is integrated into the new sub-contractor's previously exist-
ing business; (d) there is a change in supervision at the facility by
the new subcontractor; and (e) within six months after the award-
ing of the contract the previous sub-contractor's employees constitute
less than a majority of employees employed at the facility?"

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1971
64
Cases consolidated and a total of one hour allotted for oral
argument.

ORDER
Pursuant to the provisions of Title 28, U.S.C. § 42, It is ordered
that Mr. Justice Stewart be, and he is hereby, temporarily assigned to
the Fifth Circuit as Circuit Justice; and
That Mr. Justice Marshall be, and he is hereby, temporarily
assigned to the Second Circuit as Circuit Justice.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1971
ORAL ARGUMENT
122
No. 70–29. John Giglio, petitioner, v. United States. Argued by
Mr. James M. LaRossa for the petitioner and by Mr. Harry R. Sachse
for the respondent.
No. 70-58. Oliver T. Fein, petitioner, v. Selective Service System
Local Board No. 7, Yonkers, N.Y., et al. Argued by Mr. Michael B.
Standard for the petitioner and by Mr. Solicitor General Griswold
for the respondents.
No. 70-77. North Carolina, petitioner, v. Wayne Claude Rice.
☐ Argued by Mr. Jacob L. Safron for the petitioner and Mr. William W.
Van Alstyne for the respondent.
No. 70-90. John Schilb et al., appellants, v. Vincent P. Kuebel,
etc. Leave granted Mr. James A. Rooney to appear and present oral
argument for the appellees, pro hac vice, on motion of Mr. John J.
O'Toole. Argued by Mr. John J. O'Toole for the appellants and by
Mr. James A. Rooney for the appellees, pro hac vice, by special leave
of Court.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1971
124
No. 70-60. Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York,
as Liquidator of Manhattan Casualty Company, petitioner, c. Bankers

the appellee.

Nos. 70-5040, 70-5041, 70-9, 70-46, and 70-45.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 70-5040. Jack L. Mayer, appellant, v. City of Chicago. Argued
by Mr. Henry F. Field for the appellant and by Mr. Richard L. Curry
for the appellee.
No. 70-5041. Charles W. Britt, Jr., petitioner, v. North Carolina.
Argued by Mr. Robert G. Bowers for the petitioner and by Mrs.
Christine Y. Denson for the respondent.
No. 70-9. Evelle J. Younger et al., appellants, v. Robert O. Gil-
more, Jr., et al. Argued by Mr. George R. Nock for the appellants and
by Mr. John E. Wahl for the appellees.
No. 70-46. United States, petitioner, v. Dimas Campos-Serrano.
Leave granted Mr. William Bradford Reynolds to appear and pre-
sent oral argument for the petitioner, pro hac vice, on motion of Mr.
Solicitor General Erwin N. Griswold. Argued by Mr. William Brad-
ford Reynolds for the petitioner, pro hac vice, by special leave of Court
and by Mr. John J. Cleary for the respondent.
Adjourned until Monday, October 18, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
The day call for Monday, October 18, 1971, will be as follows:
Nos. 70-45, 70-71, 70-78, 70-54, and 70–93.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 70-45. United States, appellant, v. Daniel B. Brewster.
Argued by Mr. Solicitor General Erwin N. Griswold for the appellant
and by Mr. Norman P. Ramsey for the appellee.
No. 70-71. United States, petitioner, v. Denneth Bass. Argument
commenced by Mr. Roger A. Pauley for the petitioner and continued
by Mr. William E. Hellerstein for the respondent.
Mr. Justice Douglas announced that while the Chief Justice is
unavoidably absent this afternoon, he will participate in the decision.
of the cases argued.
No. 70-71. United States, petitioner, v. Denneth Bass. Argument
resumed and concluded by Mr. Hellerstein for the respondent.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1971
128
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall,
and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-149. Henry Steenhoek et al., appellants, v. Iowa. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Iowa. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 71-86. Associated Home Builders of the Greater East Bay
Incorporated, appellant, v. City of Walnut Creek et al. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question.
No. 71-5024. Philip Aquafredda, appellant, v. New York. Appeal
from the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court of New York, First
Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 71-5108. Zobe and Carrie May Cheley et al., appellants, v.
James Parham, Director of the Georgia Department of Family and
Children Services. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Northern District of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for failure
to docket the case within the time prescribed by Rule 13 of the Rules
of this Court. Shapiro v. Doe, 396 U.S. 488. Mr. Justice Douglas is of
the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set for
oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-15. Connecticut State Board of Parole, petitioner, v. John
Bey. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the District of Connecticut with directions to dis-
miss as moot. United States v. Munsingwear, 340 U.S. 36.
No. 71-5128. Charles Gaines, petitioner, v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
480-278-71-20

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1971
129
Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
of the suggestion of the Solicitor General in the memorandum for the
United States.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-356. Gerald C. Nichol, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Alfred L.
Kennan et al. The application for stay presented to the Chief Justice,
and by him referred to the Court, is denied without prejudice to an
application for a stay to the three-judge district court.
No. 70-18. Jane Roe et al., appellants, v. Henry Wade. The mo-
tion of Women for the Unborn et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici
curiae, is granted.
No. 70-52. United States, petitioner, v. Mississippi Chemical Cor-
poration et al. The motion of M.F.A. Central Cooperative et al., for
leave to participate in oral argument, as amici curiae, is denied. Mr.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.

for the Second Circuit granted.

of America et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit granted.

480-278-71-23

'
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1971
145
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
Mr. Justice Douglas said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 70-5135. Raymond Arciniega, petitioner, v. Edward R. Free-
man, U.S. Marshal. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis granted, petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-170. The Board of Visitors of the College of William and
Mary in Virginia et al., appellants, v. Ethel M. Norris et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Eastern District of
Virginia. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 71–271. Thomas Lawson et al., appellants, v. Board of Edu-
cation of the Vestal Central School District et al. Appeal from the
Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York, Third Judi-
cial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that the ques-
tion of jurisdiction should be postponed to a hearing of the case on
the merits.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-247. Gene Reale, petitioner, v. International Business Ma-
chines Corporation, et al. The application for an extension of time
within to file a petition for a writ of certiorari presented to Mr. Justice
Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice
Stewart is of the opinion that the application should be granted.
Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision
of this application.
480-278-71- -24

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1971
146
No. 70-2. United States, appellant, v. 12 200-Ft. Reels of Super
8mm. Film et al. The motion of Christopher W. Walker for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 70-6. Nellie Swarb et al., appellants, v. William M. Lennox
et al. The motion of David A. Scholl for leave to argue orally, pro hac
vice, on behalf of the appellants is granted. The motion of Pennsyl-
vania Credit Union League for reconsideration of the order denying
leave to argue orally, as amicus curiae, is denied. The motion of Amer-
ican Bankers Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is
granted. The motion of Pennsylvania Land Title Association for
leave to argue orally, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 70-34. Sierra Club, petitioner, v. Rogers C. B. Morton, Indi-
vidually, and as Secretary of the Interior of the United States et al.
The motion of the County of Tulare for leave to argue orally, as
amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 70-54. Victory Carriers, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Bill Law.
The motion of American Trial Lawyers Association for leave to file
an untimely brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 70-5009. Theon Jackson, petitioner, v. Indiana. The motion
of The American Association on Mental Deficiency et al., for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 70-5039. Margarita Fuentes et al., appellants, v. Robert L.
Shevin, Attorney General of Florida, et al. The motion of Bruce S.
Rogow for leave to permit C. Michael Abbott to argue orally, pro
hac vice, on behalf of appellants is granted.
No. 70-5138. Paul Parham et al., appellants, v. Americo V. Cortese
et al. The motion of David A. Scholl for leave to argue orally, pro
hac vice, on behalf of the appellants is granted.
No. 71-119. Mike Trbovich, petitioner, v. United Mine Workers of
America et al. The motion to expedite is granted.

Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.
No. 71–250. Barton Baker, petitioner, v. Monroe County Bar Asso-
ciation. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New
York denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari
should be granted.
No. 71-5125. Jerry Mack Dorrough, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion
that certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-5148. Omer G. Tinch, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-212. Hoover Academy, Inc., petitioner, v. Rebecca Wright
et al. Motion to dispense with printing petition and motion of respond-
ents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit denied.
No. 71-251. Rafael M. Bertuccelli, petitioner, v. William Bellamy.
Motion to dispense with printing petition granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit denied.
No. 71-258. Paul W. Briggs, Superintendent of Schools, et al., pe-
titioner, v. Vanessa Calloway, etc. Motion of respondent for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 71–264. Harry R. Booth, petitioner, v. Lemont Mfg. Corp.,
et al. Motion of petitioner to dispense with printing appendix granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit denied.
No. 71–276. John L. Zelker, Superintendent, Green Haven Cor-
rectional Facility, petitioner, v. Joseph Randazzo. Motion of respond-
ent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit denied. The Chief Justice is of the opinion that certiorari
should be granted.
No. 71-5132. James Earl Thompson, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Brennan are of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall,
and Mr. Justice Blackmun.

No. A-483. The Committee for Nuclear Responsibility, Inc., et al.,
petitioners, v. James R. Schlesinger et al. The application for an in-
junction presented to the Chief Justice, and by him referred to the
Court, is set down for oral argument at 9:30 a.m. on November 6, 1971.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

No. A-465. Hughes Tool Company et al., petitioners, v. Trans

as Liquidator of Manhattan Casualty Company, petitioner, v. Bankers
Life and Casualty Company et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.

Hartzell, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1971
162
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Writ of certiorari dis-
missed as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam announced by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.

more, Jr., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of California. Judgment affirmed. Opinion per
curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1971
163
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 70-33. Irving J. Engelman et al., appellants, v. Carolyn Amos
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
New Jersey. Motion of appellee Amos for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Judgment affirmed. Opinion per curiam.
No. 71-5179. Lynda M. Jennings, appellant, v. Jack C. Mahoney,
Director, Financial Responsibility Division, Dept. of Public Safety
of the State of Utah. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Utah. Motion
of appellant for leave to proceed herein in forma pauperis granted.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion per curiam.
No. 71-5679. Edwin James Doherty, petitioner, v. United States.
On application for appointment of counsel. Treating the application
as a motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari, motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit granted, judgment affirming conviction and
order denying appointment of counsel vacated and case remanded
to Court of Appeals for further proceedings consistent with the
opinion of this Court including reentry of its judgment of affirmance
and appropriate reconsideration of the motion for appointment of
counsel. Opinion per curiam. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-5269. Kevin B. Barnes, appellant, v. Louisiana. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 71–326. Wyman C. Lowe, etc., appellant, v. Billie B. Lowe.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
480-278-71-29

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1971
164
No. 71–332. Julian Bond and Andrew Young, etc., appellants v.
Ben W. Fortson, Jr., Secretary of State of Georgia, et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Georgia. Judgment affirmed.
No. 71-336. United Dairy Farmers Cooperative Association, ap-
pellant, v. Milk Control Commission of the Commonwealth of Penn-
sylvania et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Middle District of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed.
No. 71-340. Parey P. Branton et al., appellants, v. Mary E. Parker,
Treasurer of Louisiana, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Louisiana. Motion to dispense with printing jurisdictional statement
granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 71–348. Catherine Mealey et al., appellants, v. The City of
Laramie, Wyoming, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wyom-
ing. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-360. United Air Lines, Inc., appellant, v. Michigan et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-5170. Henry Wood and Genevera Gonzales, appellants, v.
Public Utilities Commission of California et al. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of California. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan is of the opinion that
probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set for oral agrument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-5239. George Franklin Harless, petitioner, v. John W.
Turner, Warden. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for recon-
sideration in light of this Court's decision in Coolidge v. New Hamp-
shire, 403 U.S. 443. The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice White and Mr.
Justice Blackmun dissent.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. _ _ _ Edward S. Friedland, petitioner v. Justices of the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, en banc.
Request for reconsideration of the application for extraordinary relief
denied.
No. A 404. Donald Thomas Skaggs, petitioner, v. Director De-
partment of Motor Vehicles et al. The application for a stay pre-
sented to Mr. Justice Brennan, and by him referred to the Court,
is denied.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1971
165
No. A-462. Ovide Duncantell, petitioner, v. Joe Ingraham, Judge,
etc. et al. The motion for leave to file a petition for writ of mandamus
presented to Mr. Justice Stewart, and by him referred to the Court,
is denied.
No. 9, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Louisiana et al.
The motion of the United States for entry of a supplemental decree
as to the State of Louisiana is set down for oral argument. Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 17, Original. State of Nebraska, plaintiff, v. State of Iowa. The
Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed. Exceptions,
if any, may be filed by the parties within 45 days. Reply briefs, if any,
may be filed within 30 days thereafter.
No. 27, Original. State of Ohio, plaintiff, v. State of Kentucky.
The motion for leave to file an amended bill of complaint is referred
to the Special Master.
No. 30, Original. State of Michigan, plaintiff, v. State of Ohio.
The Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed.
Exceptions, if any, may be filed by the parties within 45 days. Reply
briefs, if any, may be filed within 30 days thereafter.
No. 51, Original. Founding Church of Scientology, plaintiff, v.
Lord Cromer and Brian L. Crowe. The motion for leave to file a
bill of complaint is denied.
No. 53, Original. State of Alabama by and through George C.
Wallace, as its Governor, plaintiff, v. John B. Connally, Secretary of
the Treasury of the United States et al. The motion for leave to file
bill of complaint is denied.
No. 68–5027. Earnest James Aikens, Jr., petitioner, v. California;
No. 69-5003. William Henry Furman, petitioner, v. Georgia;
No. 69-5030. Lucious Jackson, Jr., petitioner, v. Georgia; and
No. 69-5031. Elmer Branch, petitioner, v. Texas. The motion of
Edmond G. Brown et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is
granted.
No. 70-6. Nellie Swarb et al., appellants, v. William M. Lennox
et al. The motion of the appellants to dispense with printing reply
brief is granted. The motion of the Attorney General of Pennsylvania
for additional time for oral argument is denied. The conditional mo-
tion of the Pennsylvania Bankers Association for leave to present oral
argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 70-14. Jonathan O. Cole, Superintendent, Boston State Hos-
pital, et al., appellants, v. Lucretia Peteros Richardson. The motion of
Harold Hestnes to permit Stephen H. Oleskey to argue orally, pro
hac vice, on behalf of the appellee is granted.
No. 70-18. Jane Roe et al., appellants, v. Henry Wade; and

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1971
166
No. 70-40. Mary Doe et al., appellants, v. Arthur K. Bolton, as
Attorney General of the State of Georgia, et al. The motions of Cer-
tain Physicians, Professors and Fellows of the American College of
Obstetrics and Gynecology; and the National Right to Life Commit-
tee for leave to file brief, as amicus curiae, are granted. The motion of
Ferdinand Buckley for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, in No.
70-40, is granted.
No. 70-36. Charles R. Perry et al., petitioners, v. Robert P. Sinder-
mann, etc. The motion of The American Federation of Teachers for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 70-54. Victory Carriers, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Bill Law.
The motion for reconsideration and the motion of the National Mari-
time Compensation Committee for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae.
are granted.
No. 70-75. Moose Lodge No. 107, appellant, v. K. Leroy Irvis et al.
The motion of the Attorney General of Pennsylvania for additional
time for oral argument is denied.
No. 70-79. Reliance Electric Company, petitioner, v. Emerson
Electric Company. The motion of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc.,
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 70–86. United States, petitioner, v. Forrest S. Tucker. The
motion to appoint co-counsel on behalf of the respondent and for
William A. Reppy, Jr., to present oral argument in this case is granted,
and it is ordered that William A. Reppy, Jr., Esquire, of Durham,
North Carolina, a member of the Bar of this Court, be, and he is
hereby appointed to serve as co-counsel for the respondent.
No. 70–92. California Motor Transport Co. et al., petitioners, v.
Trucking Unlimited et al. The motion of Landmarks Holding Cor-
poration et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
No. 70-113. Ford Motor Company, appellant, v. United States
et al. The motion of the Zenith Vinyl Fabrics Corporation for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.

is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted and case set for
oral argument.
No. 71-455. Gordon F. Ragland and James A. Wright, Jr., peti-
tioners, v. Tennessee. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of
Criminal Appeals of Tennessee denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the
opinion that certiorari should be granted and case set for oral argu-
ment.

'
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1971
178
No. 71-5153. Paul Bernard Couming, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted and case set for oral argument.
No. 71-5169. George Howard Christy, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion
that certiorari should be granted and case set for oral argument.
No. 71-5186. John R. Brown, petitioner, v. R. I. Moseley, Warden.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion
that certiorari should be granted and case set for oral argument.
No. 71-5226. Jean D. Dockery, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of
the opinion that certiorari should be granted and case set for oral
argument.
No. 71-5236. Billy Dean White, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion.
that certiorari should be granted and case set for oral argument.
No. 71-5247. Fred A. Cunningham, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion
that certiorari should be granted and case set for oral argument.
No. 71-5253. James Lee Parler, petitioner, v. Vincent Mancusi,
Warden. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of
the opinion that certiorari should be granted and case set for oral
argument.
No. 71-89. Evans Theatre Corporation, etc., et al., petitioner, v.
Lewis R. Slaton, etc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Su-
preme Court of Georgia denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part
in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 71-194. Pan American World Airways, Inc., petitioner, v.
Celio Diaz, Jr. Motion of the respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is
of the opinion that certiorari should be granted and case set for oral
argument.
No. 71–218. Ralph Grounds et al., petitioners, v. Northern Natural
Gas Company et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit denied as out of time. Mr.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1971
179
Justice White took no part in the consideration or decision of this peti-
tion.
No. 71–230. Newark Teachers Union, etc., et al., petitioners, v. The
Board of Education of Newark, etc. Motion of the American Civil
Liberties Union for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Mo-
tion to dispense with printing petitioners' reply brief granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate
Division, denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari
should be granted and case set for oral argument.
No. 71–285. Elva G. Anderson et al., petitioners, v. United States.
Motion to dispense with printing petition granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims denied.
No. 71-301. Harvey Franklin and Michael Frederick Dent, peti-
tioners, v. New Jersey. Motion to dispense with printing petition
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of New
Jersey, Appellate Division, denied.
No. 71-325. Albert Lee Frauhiger, petitioner, v. Ohio. Motion to
dispense with printing petition granted. Petition for writ of cretiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 71-334. Matthew Donald Johnson and Marion Ernest Mc-
Millan, petitioners, v. Texas. Motion to dispense with printing petition
granted. Petition for writ of certorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals
of Texas denied.
No. 71-338. William S. Ellis, Jr., et al., petitioners, v. Lyman T.
Harada et al. Motion to dispense with printing petition granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Hawaii denied.
No. 71-343. Joseph Smith et al., petitioners, v. Ralph Oriscello,
Sheriff of Union County. Motion to dispense with printing petition
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit denied.
No. 71-305. Edward J. Kazubowski, petitioner, v. Loy E. Ray,
Sheriff of Henry County, Illinois, et al. Application for a stay, motion
to amend petition and petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit and for other relief
denied.
No. 71–361. United States, petitioner, v. Arthur C. Schmid, Jr.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims
denied. Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Blackmun are of the opinion
that certiorari should be granted and case set for oral argument.
No. 71-363. Beckman Instruments, Incorporated, petitioner, v.
Reeves Instrument Corporation et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1971
180
Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Blackmun are of the opinion that
certorari should be granted and case set for oral argument.
No. 71-378. Kenneth G. Flickinger, etc., petitioner, v. Electric
Construction Co., Inc. Motion of National Association of Contractors
Licensing Agencies for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiate, granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona denied.
Mr. Justice Stewart is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted
and case set for oral argument.
No. 71–389. W. Tucker Blaine, Sr., et al., petitioners, v. United
States. Motion for the government to furnish list of pending similar
controversies denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 71-5266. Harry W. Theriault, petitioner, v. Virgil Pittman,
United States District Judge. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of
this petition.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRITS OF HABEAS CORPUS
No. 71-5159. Joseph White, petitioner, v. Harold J. Cardwell,
Warden. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of habeas corpus
denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 70-5188. Robert J. Riddell, petitioner, v. Orris L. Hamilton
et al. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of mandamus denied.
No. 71-5265. Harry W. Theriault, petitioner, v. United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Motion for leave to file.
petition for writ of mandamus denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
REHEARING DENIED
No. 70-115. Donald R. McVean, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for rehearing denied.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Reed (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Claims beginning November 29, 1971, and ending June 30, 1972,
and for such further time as may be required to complete unfinished
business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered on the
minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

OPINION
No. 70-97. Norfolk and Western Railway Company, petitioner,
Richard Nemitz et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun
with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice White join.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 70-70. Federal Trade Commission, petitioner, v. The Sperry
and Hutchinson Company. Argued by Mr. Richard W. McLaren for
the petitioner and by Mr. Harold L. Russell for the respondent.
No. 70-5045. Donald Lindsey et al., appellants, v. Dorothea M.
Normet et al. Argued by Mr. John H. Clough for the appellants, and
by Mr. Theodore B. Jensen for the appellees.
480-278-71-35

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1971
192
No. 70-98. Rudolph Santobello, petitioner, v. New York. Argued
by Mr. Irving Anolik for the petitioner and by Mr. Daniel J. Sullivan
for the respondent.
No. 70-38. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Florida
Power & Light Company. Argued by Mr. Samuel Huntington for the
petitioner and by Mr. Jefferson D. Giller for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1971
193
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 70-108. A. E. Slayton, Jr., Superintendent, Virginia State
Penitentiary, petitioner, v. Lawrence Furman Smith. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings con-
sistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice
Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Stewart joins, believing that the
Court of Appeals has observed all the proprieties as well as the re-
quirements of the Act, would affirm its judgment.
No. 70-353. B. Frank Camp, petitioner, v. Arkansas. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arkansas. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of Arkansas for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
No. 70-5213. Arnold Maxwell Harris, petitioner, v. Washington
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Washington. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Washington for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall
would grant the petition and reverse the judgment. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
No. 70-5343. Fred A. Cruz et al., petitioners, v. W. B. “Bill”
Hauck, etc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
480-278-71-36

GRANTED
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1971
194
consideration in light of Younger v. Gilmore, 404 U.S. -, decided
November 8, 1971. Opinion per curiam. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas.
No. 70-5376. Victor Pease, appellant, v. Laulette I. Hansen, Di-
rector, Cascade County Department of Public Welfare, et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Montana. Motion of appellant for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Montana for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
The Chief Justice is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should
be noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 71-5294. Donald Lee Schreiner, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Tenth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion per curiam. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-5249. John Van Geldern, appellant, v. California Adult
Authority. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 70-5428. Fred Sowder, appellant, v. City of Cincinnati. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 71-5280. Julius Dwaine Perry, Sr., appellant v. Texas. Appeal
from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari,
is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdic-
tion should be noted and case set for oral argument.
No. 71-5282. Beverly Stauffer Dundon, appellant, v. J. Barry
Jesmer, as Director of Social Services, etc. Appeal from the Court of
Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 35, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Maine et al.
The motion of the Florida Council of 100, Inc., for leave to file a brief,
as amicus curiae, is granted.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1971
195
No. 70-5388. Otis Loper, petitioner, v. George J. Beto, Director,
Texas Department of Corrections. The motion of the petitioner to have
A. C. Turner et al., acting members of the Board of Pardons and
Paroles of the State of Texas joined as parties respondent, is granted.
The motion of the petitioner for the appointment of counsel is granted,
and it is ordered that John T. Cabaniss, Esquire, of Houston, Texas,
be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in
this case.
No. 71-5633. Richard J. Oba, petitioner, v. United States. The
application for a stay presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him re-
ferred to the Court, is denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 71-83. John A. Strait, petitioner, v. Melvin R. Laird, Secre-
tary of Defense, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 71–288. Melvin R. Laird, Secretary of Defense, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Arlo Tatum. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
granted.
No. 71–300. Thomas L. Andrews, petitioner, v. Louisville & Nash-
ville Railroad Company et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted.
No. 71-5313. Donald L. Brooks, petitioner, v. Tennessee. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Tennessee granted
limited to Questions III and IV presented by the petition which read
as follows:
"III. The trial court was in error in refusing to allow defendant to
be placed on the witness stand after other witnesses had testified in his
behalf as said Tennessee Statute requiring defendant to be first wit-
ness is unconstitutional in violation of the Fifth Amendment and
Fourteenth Amendment of the Federal Constitution and Article I,
Section 9 of Tennessee Constitution.
"IV. Code section 40-2403 deprives a defendant of due process of
law, in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States
Constitution.”
CERTIORARI DENIED

denied.

480-278-71-39

FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1971
209
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-507. Kenneth J. Hammond et al., petitioners, v. William J.
Brown et al. The application for a stay presented to Mr. Justice
Stewart, and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas, believing that the Ohio anti-rioting statutes, Ohio Code
§§ 2923.52 to .54, on their face seem overly broad and prima facie
infringe on freedom of expression protected by the First Amendment,
would grant the stay for the reasons stated in his dissenting opinion in
Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37, 58.
No. A-516. Edward V. Hanrahan, petitioner, v. State Electoral
Board of Illinois et al.; and
No. A-523. Joseph Germano et al., petitioners, v. State Electoral
Board of Illinois. The applications for a stay presented to Mr. Justice
Blackmun, and by him referred to the Court, are denied. Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of these
applications.
480-278-71-40

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1971
210
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-5337. Ray E. Fullington et al., appellants, v. Con F. Shea,
etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of Colorado. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted and judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion
that probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set for oral argu-
ment.
No. 71-5363. Ophelia Kirkwood, appellant, v. Arthur C. Winstead,
Commissioner, etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Missis-
sippi. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan are of the opinion
that probable jurisdiction should be noted and case set for oral argu-
ment.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-520. In the Matter of Disbarment of Franklin P. Samples.
It is ordered that Franklin P. Samples, of Huntsville, Alabama, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. A-521. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frederick J. Freel.
It is ordered that Frederick J. Freel, of Jefferson, Missouri, be sus-
•KANSAS
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, city
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. A-522. In the Matter of Resignation of John E. Pratt. The
request of John E. Pratt, of Boynton Beach, Florida, that his name
be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice in this
Court is granted.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1971
211
No. 70-34. Sierra Club, petitioner, v. Rogers C. B. Morton, Indi-
vidually and as Secretary of the Interior of the United States, et al.
The motion of The Environmental Defense Fund for leave to file a
reply brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 70–153. United States, petitioner, v. United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, Southern Division, et al.
The motion of respondents, Plamondon, Forrest and Sinclair for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
No. 70-5025. Francis Haines, petitioner, v. Otto J. Kerner, For-
mer Governor, State of Illinois, et al. The motion of Boston College
Center for Corrections and the Law for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, and motion to dispense with printing are granted.
No. 71–93. Walter J. Howard et al., petitioners, v. Florida East
Coast Railway Co., Inc., et al. The motion of respondent Florida East
Coast Railway Co., Inc., for damages is denied. Mr. Justice Marshall
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 71–384. Ernest Klein, petitioner, v. John J. Bower et al. The
application for vacation of preliminary injunction is denied.

Appeals for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the
opinion that certiorari should be granted to review the question
whether the search of the bedroom bureau was incident to the arrest
of the petitioner in the basement when he was at the time of the search
outside the house in a police patrol car.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1971
ORDER
216
It is ordered that the Rules of the Supreme Court of the United
States be, and the same are hereby, amended by revising paragraph 1
of Rule 16 to read as follows:
"Within thirty days after receipt of the jurisdictional statement,
unless the time is enlarged by the court or a justice thereof, or by the
clerk under the provisions of paragraph 5 of Rule 34. the appellee may
file a printed motion to dismiss, or motion to affirm. In cases where
the United States or any agency, officer or employee thereof is the
appellee, the appellee shall have an additional twenty days to file said
motions. Where appropriate, a motion to affirm may be united in the
alternative with a motion to dismiss."
It is further ordered that paragraph 1 of Rule 24 be revised by add-
ing the following sentence to the said paragraph:
"In cases where the United States or any agency, officer or employee
thereof is the respondent, the respondent shall have an additional
twenty days to file the said opposing brief."

OPINIONS
No. 70-53. Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Health, Education
and Welfare, appellant, v. Raymond Belcher. Appeal from the United.
States District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Southern District of West Virginia for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan joins.
No. 70-4. Sally M. Reed, appellant, v. Cecil R. Reed, Administra-
tor, etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Idaho. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Idaho for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Chief Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Monday, December 6, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
☑

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1971
222
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart. Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-577. Stephen S. Chandler, U.S. District Judge for the
Western District of Oklahoma, petitioner, v. William H. Pat O'Bryan.
The application for extension of time to file a petition for a writ of
certiorari and stay of mandate presented to Mr. Justice White, and
by him referred to the Court, is granted, and it is ordered that the
time for filing a petition for a writ of certiorari be extended, and the
mandate of the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
be stayed, until January 7, 1972. If the petition for writ of certiorari
be filed on or before January 7, 1972, then the mandate is further
stayed pending the disposition of the petition for a writ of certiorari.
Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of
this application.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1971
224
No. 70-65. Texas State Tile & Terrazzo Co., Inc., et al., petitioners,
e. Plasterer's Local Union No. 79, etc., et al. On writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White.
No. 70-11. Chevron Oil Company, petitioner, v. Gaines Ted
Huson. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart.
Separate opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 70-5025. Francis Haines, petitioner, v. Otto J. Kerner, For-
mer Governor, State of Illinois, et al. Argued by Mr. Stanley A. Bass
for the petitioner and by Mr. Warren K. Smoot for the respondents,
pro hac vice, by special leave of Court.
No. 70-5015. Jon Richard Argersinger, petitioner, v. Raymond
Hamlin, Sheriff, Leon County, Florida. Argued by Mr. J. Michael
Shea for the petitioner, pro hac vice, by special leave of Court, and
by Mr. George R. Georgieff for the respondents.
No. 70-47. Florence Diffenderfer and Nishan Paul, appellants, v.
Central Baptist Church of Miami, Florida, Incorporated, et al. Argued
by Mr. Leo Pfeffer for appellant Florence Diffenderfer, by Mr.
Howard J. Hollander for appellant Nishan Paul and by Mr. Charles
M. Whelan for the appellees.
No. 70-55. Board of Regents of the University of Texas System,
appellant, v. New Left Education Project et al. Argued by Mr. W. O.
Shultz II for the appellant and by Mr. David R. Richards for the
respondents. AppELLEES
No. 70-5026. Claude Alexander, petitioner, v. Louisiana. Argu-,
ment commenced by Mr. Charles Stephen Ralston for the petitioner.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.
Х

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1971
225
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-12. Russell Bartley et al., appellants, v. Elliot L. Richard-
son, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky.
Judgment, holding constitutional § 224 of the Social Security Act, 42
USC (Supp. v., 1965–69) 424a, affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents
on the basis of his dissent in Richardson v. Belcher, 401 U.S.
(1971)
No. 71-306. Robert B. Carleson et al., appellants, v. Elizabeth
Taylor et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of California. Motion of appellees for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 71-436. Emhart Corporation, appellant, v. Pennsylvania. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Middle District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers where-
on the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
is denied.
No. 71–457. Village of West Milwaukee et al., appellants, v. Area
Board of Vocational, Technical and Adult Education (District 9).
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-475. Lisa Hoffman, appellant, v. Dale Carson, as Sheriff
of Duval County and the Consolidated City of Jacksonville, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed.
for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas is
of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted.

|
TUESDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1971
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
226
No. A-544. Paul Dadurian, petitioner, v. United States. The appli-
cation for bail and/or stay of mandate presented to Mr. Justice
Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice'
Stewart is of the opinion that the application should be granted.
No. 70-18. Jane Roe et al., appellants, v. Henry Wade. The motion
of the appellee to postpone oral argument is denied.
No. 70-55. Board of Regents of the University of Texas System,
appellant, v. New Left Education Project et al. The motion of the
appellant to postpone oral argument is denied.
No. 70-5015. Jon Richard Argersinger, petitioner, v. Raymond
Hamlin, Sheriff, Leon County, Florida. The motion of Bruce S. Ragow
for leave to permit J. Michael Shea to argue orally, pro hac vice,
on behalf of the petitioner, is granted.
No. 70-5025. Francis Haines, petitioner, v. Otto J. Kerner, Former
Governor, State of Illinois, et al. The motion of the National Law
Office of the National Legal Aid and Defenders Association for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, and motion to dispense with
printing are granted.
No. 70-5146. Millard Robert Beasley, petitioner, v. United States.
The order dated November 16, 1971, denying petition for rehearing
in this case vacated pending further order of this Court.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 71-11. James R. James, Judicial Administrator, et al., appel-
lants, v. David E. Strange. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Kansas. In this case probable jurisdiction is
noted.
No. 71-422. Lake Carriers' Association et al., appellants, v. Ralph
A. MacMullan et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Michigan. In this case probable jurisdiction is
noted.

reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-

Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White. Mr.
Justice Brennan would affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals
for the reasons stated in Part I of the dissenting opinion of Mr. Jus-
tice White.

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1971
241
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 70-5308. Alan Daniel Wilwording et al., petitioners, v. Harold
R. Swenson, Warden. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Motions for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion per curiam. Mr. Justice Blackmun concurs in the judgment and in
Part II of the Court's per curiam opinion. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Chief Justice Burger.
No. 71–262. William M. O'Keeffe, Deputy Commissioner, Sixth
Compensation District, Department of Labor, petitioner, v. Aerojet-
General Shipyards, Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed, and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-349. Herman Eger, appellant, v. Florida State Board of
Dentistry. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-478. Edward T. Weaver, Director, Illinois Department of
Public Aid, et al., appellants, v. Jane Doe, etc. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.
Motion of appellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Judgment affirmed.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-190. Herbert Paul Hartstein, petitioner, v. Missouri. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Missouri.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted and judgment reversed. Redrup
480-278-71-49

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1971
242
v. New York, 386 U.S. 767 (1967). The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice
White and Mr. Justice Blackmun dissent.
No. 71-443. Donald J. Wiener and Wiley Gene Dulin, petitioners,
v. California. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate De-
partment of the Superior Court of California, County of San Diego.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted and judgment reversed. Redrup
v. New York, 386 U.S. 767 (1967). The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice White
and Mr. Justice Blackmun dissent.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. The motion of the State of Louisiana for relief pur-
suant to Rule 60(b) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure is denied.
Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision
of this motion.
No. 40, Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, plaintiff, v.
State of New York et al. The Report of the Special Master is received
and ordered filed. Exceptions, if any, may be filed by the parties within
45 days. Reply briefs, if any, may be filed within 30 days thereafter.
No. A-342. Angelo Bruno Annaloro, appellant, v. Albert Elias,
Superintendent, Yardville Youth Reception and Detention Center.
The renewed application for bail pending appeal is denied. Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas is of the opinion that bail should be granted. Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.
No. A-482. Sidney G. Babbitz, petitioner, v. E. Michael McCann,
District Attorney of Milwaukee County, et al. The application for a
stay presented to Mr. Justice Marshall, and by him referred to the
Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that the appli-
cation should be granted.
No. A-578. Alan J. Dixon et al., petitioners, v. Sherman Skolnick
et al. The application for a stay and for other relief presented to Mr.
Justice Blackmun, and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.
No. 70-92. California Motor Transport Co., et al., petitioners, v.
Trucking Unlimited et al. The motion for leave to file a supplemental
brief, after argument, is granted.
No. 70-295. First National City Bank, petitioner, v. Banco
Nacional de Cuba. The request for additional time for oral argument
is denied.

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1971
243
No. 71-162. The Board of Regents of State Colleges et al., peti-
tioners, v, David F. Roth, etc. The motion of American Federation of
Teachers for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 71-415. Colorado River Water Conservation District, peti-
tioner, v. Rocky Mountain Power Company et al. The Solicitor Gen-
eral is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the
United States.

et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit denied.

granted and case set for oral argument.

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1971
249
No. 71–219. Charles Vernon Hawkins, petitioner, v. United States.
Motion for leave to proceed further herein in forma pauper is granted.
Petition for rehearing denied.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit during the week of February 7, 1972,
and for such additional time in advance thereof to prepare for the trial
of cases, and for such further time as may be required to complete un-
finished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered on
the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, December 20, 1971, until
Monday, January 10, 1972.

OPINION
No. 70-77. North Carolina, petitioner, v. Wayne Claude Rice. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for consideration of the question of mootness. Opinion per curiam
announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Douglas would
affirm the judgment below on the opinion of the Court of Appeals in
434 F.2d 297.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff v. State of
Louisiana et al. Argued on the motion of the United States for entry
of a supplemental decree as to the State of Louisiana by Mr. Solicitor
General Erwin N. Griswold for the plaintiff and by Mr. Victor A.
Sachse for defendant State of Louisiana.
Adjourned until Monday, December 20, 1971, at 10 o'clock.
☑

MONDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1971
254
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced, orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-315. Resolute Insurance Company et al., appellants, v. The
Seventh Judicial District Court of Oklahoma County, State of Okla-
homa, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Western District of Oklahoma. Judgment affirmed.
No. 71-425. Dan Coit et al., appellants, v. William H. Green et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia. Judgment affirmed.
No. 71–296. First Mercantile Consumer Discount Company et al.,
appellants, v. Lindley Henry, Jr., et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stewart are
of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted and case
set for oral argument.
No. 71-329. Richard Corsetti dba Dick's Market, appellant v.
Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control, etc. Appeal from the
Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71–5379. Jane Heidel, appellant, v. Arizona State Department
of Public Welfare et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arizona.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan
are of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted and case
set for oral argument.
No. 71-5414. Maurice H. Hardeman, appellant, v. California and
Lyle Smith et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
480-278-71-51

MONDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1971
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
255
No. A-611. Curtis Holt, Sr., appellant, v. City of Richmond et al.
The application to vacate the stay order of the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit presented to the Chief Justice, and
by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the
opinion that the stay order should be vacated.
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. The motion of the United States for entry of a sup-
plemental decree as to the State of Louisiana is granted.
No. 52, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Florida. The Report of the Special Master upon the motion by the
United States to dismiss the counterclaim and deny the demand for
a jury trial filed by the State of Florida is received, filed and adopted
by the Court.
No. 71–123. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Burns
International Security Services, Inc., et al.; and
No. 71–198. Burns International Security Services, Inc., petitioner,
v. National Labor Relations Board et al. The motion of respondent
International Union, United Plant Guard Workers of America, for
additional time for oral argument is granted and 15 minutes are
allotted to the Union for that purpose. The Burns International Se-
curity Services, Inc., is allotted 15 additional minutes for oral argu-
ment.
No. 71–269. National Brewing Company, petitioner, v. Robert
Caldwell, individually and on behalf of all those similarly situated,
et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief expressing the
views of the United States.
No. 71-5097. Harold Eugene Huffman, petitioner, v. Faye I.
Boersen. The motion of petitioner for appointment of counsel is
granted, and it is ordered that Leo Eisenstatt, Esquire, of Omaha,
Nebraska, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the
petitioner in this case.
No. 70-5015. Jon Richard Argersinger, petitioner, v. Raymond
Hamlin, Sheriff, Leon County, Florida. This case is restored to the
calendar for reargument. The Solicitor General is invited to file a
brief expressing the views of the United States.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 71–36. California et al., appellants, v. Robert LaRue et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Central District
of California. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.

No. 71-5398. Joseph T. Bethea, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit denied.
No. 71-5401. Donald Pinzon Walker, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 71-5402. John Taylor Queen, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit denied.
