MONDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1971
259
No. 71-5403. Warren E. Cronan, petitioner, v. Vincent R. Mancusi,
Warden. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit denied.
No. 71-5404. Steven Patrick Longo, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 71-5406. Malcolm J. Saulsbury, II, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 71-5408. Clarence Lothridge et al., petitioners, v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 71-53. Junius Redwood, petitioner, v. New York. Motion to
dispense with printing petition granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court of New York, First
Judicial District, denied.
No. 71-339. Jack Kershaw, petitioner, v. Tennessee. Motion to dis-
pense with printing petition granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Middle Division, denied.
No. 71-141. Jo Ann Colligan, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Activities
Club of New York, Ltd., aka New York Winter Ski Club, et al. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Stewart are of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 71–265. William Walter dba Classic Art Theatres I and II et al.,
petitioners, v. Lewis R. Slayton, District Attorney, Atlanta Judicial
Circuit, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Georgia denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari
should be granted.
No. 71-428. John Bacall et al., petitioners, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-435. John Michael Ryan, petitioner, v. Curtis W. Tarr, etc.,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the
opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-5312. Vincent S. Henderson, petitioner, v. City of Kansas
City, Missouri. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Missouri denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari
should be granted.
No. 71–293. Wayne Goham and Dennis Tyndall, petitioner, v.
Nebraska. Motion to dispense with printing petition and reply brief

MONDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1971
260
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Nebraska denied.
No. 71-313. Ray Page, Superintendent of Public Instruction, et al.,
petitioners, v. Jessel Williams, a minor, by Cornelia Williams, his
mother and next friend, et al. Motion of respondents Alexander et al.,
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit denied.
No. 71-327. Texas Gulf Sulphur Company et al., petitioners, v.
Securities and Exchange Commission;
No. 71-328. Earl L. Huntington, petitioner, v. Securities and Ex-
change Commission;
No. 71–346. David M. Crawford, petitioner, v. Securities and Ex-
change Commission; and
No. 71-347. Walter Holyk, Kenneth H. Darke and Richard H.
Clayton, petitioners, v. Securities and Exchange Commission. Petitions
for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Blackmun
are of the opinion that certiorari should be granted in No. 71–327. Mr.
Justice Blackmun is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted
limited to Question 5 in No. 71-346 and limited to Questions 6 and 7 in
No. 71-347.
No. 71-421. Texas Gulf Sulphur Company et al., petitioners, v.
Walter A. Mitchell and George Gordon Reynolds. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Cir-
cuit denied. Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Blackmun are of
the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-446. Hammond Lead Products, Inc., petitioner, v. United
States (Ralph Valls, party-in-interest). Petition for writ of certi-
orari to the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals
denied. Mr. Justice Stewart is of the opinion that certiorari should
be granted.
No. 71-458. Cities of Texarkana, Texas and Texarkana, Arkansas,
et al., petitioners, v. Civil Aeronautics Board. Motion for leave to file.
copies of decisions of Administrative Agency as an unprinted ap-
pendix granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied.
No. 71-5531. Robert Edward Lipscomb, petitioner, v. Warden, et
al., etc. Motion for leave to supplement petition granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit denied.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1971

ORDER
It is ordered by the Court that Frank M. Hepler be, and he is hereby,
appointed Marshal of this Court effective January 1, 1972.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1971
OPINIONS
266
No. 70-90. John Schilb et al., appellants, v. Vincent P. Kuebel, etc.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 70-71. United States, petitioner, v. Denneth Bass. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan joins the judgment of the Court and the opinion except
for Part III. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom
Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.
No. 70-19. United States, appellant, v. William R. Marion and
Samuel C. Cratch. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of Columbia. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the District of Columbia for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join concurring in the result.
No. 70-46. United States, petitioner, v. Dimas Campos-Serrano. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sev-
enth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Chief Jus-
tice Burger and Mr. Justice White join.
No. 70–96. Philip J. Picard, petitioner, v. James J. Connor. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
No. 70-5021. Georgia Townsend, etc., appellant, v. Harold O.
Swank, Director, Illinois Department of Public Aid, et al.; and
No. 70-5032. Loverta Alexander et al., appellants, v. Harold O.
Swank et al. Appeals for the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Illinois. Judgment reversed and cases remanded
to the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1971
267
Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Statement by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger concurring in the judgment.
No. 70-98. Rudolph Santobello, petitioner, v. New York. On writ of
certiorari to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New
York, First Judicial Department. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York,
First Judicial Department for further consideration not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stewart
join concurring in part and dissenting in part.
Adjourned until Monday, January 10, 1972, at 10 o'clock.
☑

FRIDAY, JANUARY 7, 1972
268
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist.
The Chief Justice said:
"In this special sitting of the Court, we will receive the commission
of the Justice-designate Powell and at this time the Court recognizes
the Attorney General.
"Mr. Attorney General."
Mr. Attorney General Mitchell said:
"Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court:
"I am happy to advise that the President of the United States has
nominated, the Senate has consented and the President has appointed
Mr. Lewis F. Powell, Jr., of Virginia, as an Associate Justice of the
Supreme Court of the United States.
"I bear with me the commission, dated December 9, 1971, signed by
the President of the United States, and attested by me as Attorney
General, and with the permission of the Court, I will turn the com-
mission over to the Clerk of the Court."
The Chief Justice said:
"The commission is accepted, Mr. Attorney General.
"Thank you.
"Mr. Clerk, will you read the commission."
The Clerk said:
"The commission reads as follows:
"RICHARD NIXON,
"President of the United States of America.
"To All Who shall See These Presents, Greeting:
"Know Ye; That reposing special trust and confidence in the Wis-
dom, Uprightness, and Learning of Lewis F. Powell, Jr., of Virginia,
I have nominated and, by and with the advice and consent of the
Senate, do appoint him an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of
the United States, and do authorize and empower him to execute and
fulfill the duties of that Office according to the Constitution and Laws
of the said United States, and to have and to hold the said office, with
all the powers, privileges and emoluments to the same of right ap-
pertaining, unto Him, the said Lewis F. Powell, Jr., during his good
behavior.
480-278-72—53

FRIDAY, JANUARY 7, 1972
269
"In testimony whereof, I have caused these Letters to be made patent
and the seal of the Department of Justice to be hereunto affixed.
"Done in the City of Washington, this 9th day of December, in the
year of our Lord one thousand nine hundred and seventy-one, and of
the Independence of the United States of America the one hundred and
ninety-sixth."
Signed, Richard Nixon, and attested by John N. Mitchell, Attorney
General, with the seal of the Department of Justice affixed.
The Justice designate was then escorted by the Clerk to the center
of the bench.
The Chief Justice said:
"Please raise your right hand, Mr. Powell, and repeat after me:
(The following oath was administered by the Chief Justice and re-
peated by Mr. Powell :)
"I, Lewis F. Powell, Jr., do solemnly swear that I will administer
justice without respect to persons, and do equal right to the poor and
to the rich, and that I will faithfully and impartially discharge and
perform all the duties incumbent upon me as an Associate Justice of the
Supreme Court of the United States, according to the best of my
abilities and understanding, agreeably to the Constitution of the
United States; and that I will support and defend the Constitution
of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I
will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I take this obliga-
tion freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and
that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties of the office on which
I am about to enter.
"So help me God."
The Chief Justice said:
"Will you please robe the new Justice.“
Justice Powell was assisted in putting on his robe and was escorted
by the Marshal to his seat on the bench.
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Justice Powell, on behalf of all members of the Court, I
welcome you to this bench and we look forward to many years of work.
together in our common calling."
The Chief Justice said:
"In this special sitting of the Court, we will receive the commission
of the Justice-designate Rehnquist and at this time the Court recog-
nizes the Attorney General.
"Mr. Attorney General."

FRIDAY, JANUARY 7, 1972
Mr. Attorney General Mitchell said:
"Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court:
270
"I am happy to advise that the President of the United States has
nominated, the Senate has consented and the President has appointed
Mr. William H. Rehnquist, of Arizona, as an Associate Justice of
the Supreme Court of the United States.
"I bear with me the commission, dated December 15, 1971, signed
by the President of the United States, and attested by me as Attorney
General, and with the permission of the Court, I will turn the com-
mission over to the Clerk of the Court.“
The Chief Justice said:
"The commission is accepted. Mr. Attorney General.
"Thank you.
"Mr. Clerk, will you read the commission."
The Chief Justice said: CLERK SAID.
"The commission reads as follows:
"RICHARD NIXON,
"President of the United States of America,
"To All Who shall See These Presents, Greeting:
"Know Ye; That reposing special trust and confidence in the Wis-
dom, Uprightness, and Learning of William H. Rehnquist, or Arizona,
I have nominated and, by and with the advice and consent of the
Senate, do appoint him an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of
the United States, and do authorize and empower him to execute and
fulfill the duties of that Office according to the Constitution and Laws
of the said United States, and to have and to hold the said office, with
all the powers, privileges and emoluments to the same of right apper-
taining, unto Him, the said William H. Rehnquist, during his good
behavior.
"In testimony whereof, I have caused these Letters to be made
patent and the seal of the Department of Justice to be hereunto affixed.
"Done in the City of Washington, this 15th day of December, in the
year of our Lord one thousand nine hundred and seventy-one, and of
the Independence of the United States of America the one hundred
and ninety-sixth."
Signed, Richard Nixon, and attested by John N. Mitchell. Attorney
General, with the seal of the Department of Justice affixed.
The Justice designate was then escorted by the Clerk to the center
of the bench.
The Chief Justice said:
"Please raise your right hand, Mr. Rehnquist, and repeat after me:
(The following oath was administered by the Chief Justice and
repeated by Mr. Rehnquist :)

FRIDAY, JANUARY 7, 1972
271
"I, William H. Rehnquist, do solemnly swear that I will administer
justice without respect to persons, and do equal right to the poor and
to the rich, and that I will faithfully and impartially discharge and
perform all the duties incumbent upon me as an Associate Justice of
the Supreme Court of the United States, according to the best of my
abilities and understanding, agreeably to the Constitution of the United
States; and that I will support and defend the Constitution of the
United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will
bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I take this obligation
freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and
that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties of the office on
which I am about to enter.
"So help me God."
The Chief Justice said:
"Will you please robe the new Justice."
Justice Rehnquist was assisted in putting on his robe and was
escorted by the Marshal to his seat on the bench.
"The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Justice Rehnquist, on behalf of all members of the Court, I
welcome you to this bench and we look forward to many years of work
together in our common calling."
ORDER
It is ordered that the following allotment be made of the Chief Jus-
tice and Associate Justices of this Court among the circuits, pursuant
to Title 28, United States Code, Section 42 and that such allotment
be entered of record, viz:
For the District of Columbia Circuit, Warren E. Burger, Chief
Justice,
For the First Circuit, William J. Brennan, Jr., Associate Justice,
For the Second Circuit, Thurgood Marshall, Associate Justice,
For the Third Circuit, William J. Brennan, Jr., Associate Justice,
For the Fourth Circuit, Warren E. Burger, Chief Justice,
For the Fifth Circuit, Lewis F. Powell, Jr., Associate Justice,
For the Sixth Circuit, Potter Stewart, Associate Justice,
For the Seventh Circuit, William H. Rehnquist, Associate Justice,
For the Eighth Circuit, Harry A. Blackmun, Associate Justice,
For the Ninth Circuit, William O. Douglas, Associate Justice,
For the Tenth Circuit, Byron R. White, Associate Justice.
Whereupon the Court adjourned until Monday, January 10, 1972. at
10 o'clock.
☑
帶

MONDAY, JANUARY 10, 1972
272
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-5305. Florence Digesualdo et al., appellants, v. Con F.
Shea et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of Colorado. Motion of appellants for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of Colorado for further consid-
eration in light of Towsend v. Swank, 404 U.S. -
(1971).
No. 71-337. Richard Oliver Brown, appellant, v. Colorado. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas would
note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 71-463. Joseph M. Kadans, appellant, v. Jon R. Collins et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan
would treat the appeal papers as a petition for writ of certiorari and
grant the petition.
No. 71-474. Vincent Lynch dba Brewster Products, appellant, v.
Winton Blount, Postmaster General of the United States, et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Southern District of
New York. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would note prob-
able jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 71-569. Charles Carolyne, appellant, v. Youngstown State
University et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Mahoning
County. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 71-571. General Motors Corporation, appellant, v. City of
Los Angeles. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this appeal.
480-278-72-54

MONDAY, JANUARY 10, 1972
273
No. 71-5297. Elvira Sekeres, appellant, v. Illinois. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-64. Lykes Bros. Steamship Company, Inc., petitioner, v.
Joseph Chagois. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further consideration in light of Victory Carriers, Inc.
v. Law, 404 U.S. (1971). Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from the
remand. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
-
No. 70-5047. John Wyatt Mullins, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
of United States v. Bass, 404 U.S. (1971). Mr. Justice Blackmun
with whom the Chief Justice joins, dissents for the reasons stated in
his dissenting opinion in United States v. Bass, 404 U.S. (1971).
Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion and petition.
No. 70-5073. Earthia B. Wiley, petitioner, v. United States;
No. 70-5074. John Arthur Taylor, petitioner, v. United States;
and
No. 70-5095. Dale Einar Synnes, petitioner, v. United States. On
petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit.
Motions for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petitions for
writs of certiorari granted. Judgments vacated and cases remar.ded
to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of
United States v. Bass, 404 U.S. — (1971). Mr. Justice Blackmun.
with whom the Chief Justice joins, dissents for the reasons
stated in his dissenting opinion in United States v. Bass, 404 U.S.
(1971). Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part
in the consideration or decision of these motions and petitions.
No. 70-5267. Hayden Thopless Crow, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in

light of United States v. Bass, 404 U.S. (1971). Mr. Justice

in the consideration or decision of this motion and petition.

of Illinois for further consideration in light of Mayer v. City of
Chicago, 404 U.S. (1971). Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion
and petition.

No. A-357. Fred L. Bell, petitioner, v. United States. The applica-

and by him referred to the Court, is denied.

plication for bail is denied.
No. A-659. Oscar Chason, petitioner, v. United States. The re-
newed application for stay and bail is denied.
No. 70-36. Charles R. Perry et al., petitioners, v. Robert P. Sinder-
mann, etc. The request for two counsel to argue on behalf of the
petitioners is denied.
No. 70-72. United States petitioner, v. Chas. Pfizer & Co., Inc.,
et al. The motion of the respondents for additional time for oral
argument and for three counsel to argue is denied. Mr. Justice Stewart,
Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.
No.70-74. Pipefitters Local Union No. 562 et al., petitioners, v.
United States. The motion of the American Civil Liberties Union for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 70-105. Edward V. Hanrahan, State's Attorney of Cook
County, Illinois, appellant, v. Jane Doe and Sally Roe, etc., et al.; and
No. 70-106. Bart Heffernan, Guardian ad litem, appellant, v.
Jane Doe and Sally Roe, etc., et al. The motion of the appellees to
vacate the stay order entered by Mr. Justice Marshall on February 10,
1971, is denied.
No. 70–153. United States, petitioner, v. United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, Southern Division, et al.
The motion of respondents for additional time for oral argument is
granted, and a total of two hours allotted for oral argument. The Solic-
itor General is allotted one hour to argue on behalf of the United
States; counsel for named respondent is allotted one half hour and
counsel for the unnamed respondents is allotted one half hour. Mr.
Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 70-286. Iowa Beef Packers, Inc., petitioners, v. Edward D.
Thompson et al. The motion requesting that the writ of certiorari be
dismissed as improvdently granted is deferred to the hearing of the
case on the merits.
No. 70-5012. George William Milton, petitioner, v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Director, Florida Division of Corrections. The motion of J.
Robert Olian for leave to argue pro hac vice on behalf of respondent
is granted.

tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 71-5463. Betty I. Grubb et al., petitioners, v. Workmen's
Compensation Appeals Board et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District, denied.
No. 71-5469. Mitchell Wayne Barbour, petitioner, v. North Caro-
lina. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of North
Carolina denied.
No. 71-5471. Charles Tony Bennett, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 71–5472. Wade Hampton Blanks, petitioner, v. Maryland. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Special Appeals of Mary-
land denied.
No. 71-5475. William Cagle, Jr., petitioner, v. United States. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia Circuit denied.
No. 70–193. Leonard Russo, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice White took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this petition.
No. 70-280. Robert Summerlin, petitioner, v. Ohio. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted and
judgment reversed.
No. 70-5060. Dimas Campos-Serrano, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 71–480. Melvin Harvey Tobias, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.

Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.

for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the

granted.

No. 71-500. Lowell M. Birrell, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the

sideration or decision of this petition.
No. 71-518. Georgia Couch, Administratrix of the Estate of Otis
O. Couch, petitioner, v. Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad Company.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Oklahoma.
Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan are of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted and judgment reversed. Rogers v. Mo.
Pac. R. Co. 352 U.S. 500.
No. 71-520. Charles L. McKendrick, Warden, petitioner, v. Milton
Rivera. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit denied.
No. 71-555. Gary Lee McIntyre, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this petition.
No. 71-567. Richardo Arredondo, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall
are of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-5357. Crispin Santos, petitioner, v. New York State Board
of Parole. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice White and Mr. Justice Marshall are of the opinion that certiorari
should be granted.

ardson, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.

States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-

LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 71-464. Joseph M. Kadans, petitioner, v. Roger D. Foley
et al.; and
No. 71-5425. James J. Laughlin, petitioner, v. United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Motions for
leave to file petitions for writs of mandamus denied.
No. 71-5277. Albert H. Carter, petitioner, v. Court of Criminal
Appeals of Texas. The application for stay of further court proceedings
presented to Mr. Justice Stewart, and by him referred to the Court, is
denied. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of mandamus
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that the motion for leave
to file petition for writ of mandamus should be granted.

OPINIONS
No. 70-61. Securities and Exchange Commission, petitioner, v.
Medical Committee for Human Rights. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Cir-
cuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
dismissal.

MONDAY, JANUARY 10, 1972
296
Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-47. Florence Diffenderfer and Nishan Paul, appellants, v.
Central Baptist Church of Miami, Florida, Incorporated, et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the Southern District
of Florida. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the Southern District of Florida with leave to the
appellants to amend their pleadings. Opinion per curiam announced
by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
The Chief Justice said:
"Since the last regular sitting of the Court in December, our be-
loved brother, Mr. Justice John Marshall Harlan, died, and it is
appro-
priate that we take note today of his death on December 29, 1971.
"Much has already been written in professional journals and in the
nation's press of the life and work of Justice Harlan, and much more
will be said and written. Everyone acknowledges his great contribution
to work of the Court in which he dedicated so large a part of his
career in the law.
"For us in the Court, however, the loss is far more than the loss of
a colleague valued for his great legal abilities, for his penetrating
mind, and as a prodigious worker. He was all of these, but to us he was
much more. The deep personal loss to us in the departure of a beloved
friend whose warmth and gaiety lightened all the burdens and cheered
all the gatherings of the Justices of this Court for sixteen years. Words
are inadequate to express the deep affection felt for John Harlan and
our admiration for his gallant courage in adversity and illness. We
will miss him greatly.
"In due course there will be an appropriate memorial proceeding in
this Court and a date will be fixed for that purpose."
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 69–5035. Frank Johnson, appellant, v. Louisiana. Reargued
by Mr. Richard A. Buckley for the appellant and by Mrs. Louise Korns
for the appellee.
No. 69-5046. Robert Apodaca, Harry Morgan Cooper, Jr., and
James Arnold Madden, petitioners, v. Oregon. Reargued by Mr.
Richard B. Sobol for the petitioners and by Mr. Jacob B. Tanzer for
the respondent.

OPINIONS
No. 79-79. Reliance Electric Company, petitioner, v. Emerson
Electric Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice White join. Mr. Justice Powell
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.
No. 70–86. United States, petitioner, v. Forrest S. Tucker. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Chief Justice
Burger joins. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
The Chief Justice said :
"As we hear arguments in this first session of 1972, it is appropriate
that we take note that this is the first time in 35 years that Mr. Perry
Lippitt is not a part of the staff of the Supreme Court.
"Mr. Lippitt retired as Marshal of the Court on December 31, but
observers will have noted that on last Friday, January 7, one week after
his retirement, he was present in the courtroom to collaborate with his
successor for the oath-taking ceremonies of our two new colleagues.
This was typical of Perry Lippitt's dedication to duty and loyalty to
the Court that he served so long.
480-278-72- -58

TUESDAY, JANUARY 11, 1972
299
"During his tenure at the Court he served with nearly one-third of
all the 100 Justices of the Court and five Chief Justices commencing
with his appointment in the time of Chief Justice Hughes.
"Mr. Lippitt leaves with the warmest wishes of the Court and the
staff of the Court for all good things in the years ahead."

curiae.

District of Washington. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas
would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.

Governor of New York State, et al. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for

taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

CERTIORARI GRANTED
306
No. 71-492. Lloyd Corporation, Ltd., petitioner, v. Donald M.
Tanner et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 71–559. United States, petitioner, v. Chester Fuller, et al. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 71-315. Deepsouth Packing Co., Inc., petitioner, v. The
Laitram Corporation. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted limited to Ques-
tion 1 presented by the petition which reads as follows:
"1. Is an apparatus claim of a United States patent directed to a
combination of elements, each of which is old, infringed under 35
U.S.C. § 271 (a) when:
(a) although the individual elements are manufactured in the
United States,
(b) the individual elements are never assembled in the United
States, and
(c) the first and only assembly of the elemental parts into an oper-
able combination or apparatus occurs, and all testing, adjustment,
modification and use of the assembled apparatus is conducted in, a
foreign country?"
No. 71-507. Wilfred Keyes et al., petitioners, v. School District
No. 1, Denver, Colorado, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit granted. Mr.
Justice White took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 71-573. Melvin Laird, Secretary of Defense, et al., petitioners,
v. Jim Nick Nelms et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 71-5255. Willie Mae Barker, petitioner, v. John W. Wingo,
Warden. Motion for leave to proceed herein in forma pauperis and
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit granted.

No. 70-173. Aluminum Company of America, et al., petitioners,
v. Woods Exploration & Producing Company, Inc., et al. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
denied. Mr. Justice Stewart is of the opinion that certiorari should be
granted.
No. 71-121. Pro-Football, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Norman F.
Hecht et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall are of the
opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-498. Robert Olff, by and through his guardian ad litem,
Mrs. Sonny Olff, petitioner, v. East Side Union High School District.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
No. 71-578. Martha Ann Lynch Porter, et al., petitioners, v. Bert
A. Lynch Jr. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice White
and Mr. Justice Blackmun are of the opinion that certiorari should
be granted.
No. 71–580. Charles Calvin Kellis, petitioner, v. United States.
Motion to dispense with printing petition granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit denied.
No. 71-606. Charles Thomas Collins, petitioner, v. W. G. Black,
Superintendent. Motion to dispense with printing petition granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 71-583. Neville M. Tucker, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that cer-
tiorari should be granted.
No. 71-594. Frank Zizzo, petitioner, v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.
No. 71–613. Delta Malancon, petitioner, v. RMK-BRJ, a Joint
Venture. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the
opinion that certiorari should be granted.

MONDAY, JANUARY 17, 1972
312
No. 71-5185. Calvin Kearney, petitioner, v. Harry Fritz, Super-
intendent of Auburn Correctional Facility, et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should
be granted.
No. 71-5484. Jack Joseph Pryor, petitioner, v. United States. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-5508. John Huey Honore, petitioner, v. United States. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-604. Robert Anthony White, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 71-608. C.T.S. Company, Inc., petitioner, v. Cornwell Quality
Tools Co.; and
No. 71-697. Cornwell Quality Tools Co., petitioner, v. C.T.S.
Company, Inc. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted in No. 71–608.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
these petitions.
No. 71-5162. Juan Manuel Mojarro Padilla, petitioner, v. Arizona.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall are of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-5286. Martin Sostre, petitioner, v. Russell G. Oswald,
Commissioner of Corrections of State of New York, et al. Motion of
Wisconsin Judicare for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, and to
dispense with printing granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-5405. Robert Joe Robins, petitioner, v. United States. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall
join.

MONDAY, JANUARY 17, 1972
313
No. 71-5459. Wilbert Polk, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan concurs.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 71–262. William O'Keeffe, Deputy Commissioner, Sixth Com-
pensation District, Department of Labor, petitioner, v. Aerojet-Gen-
eral Shipyards, Inc.;
No. 71–393. Alphonzo L. Dowell et ux., petitioners, v. United
States;
No. 71-443. Donald J. Wiener and Wiley Gene Dulin, petitioners,
v. California;
No. 71-5081. Albert H. Carter, petitioner, v. Texas; and
No. 71-5392. John C. Bennett, petitioner, v. United States Direc-
tor of Internal Revenue, etc., et al. Petitions for rehearing denied.
ASSIGNMENT ORDERS
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Jus-
tice Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit during the period beginning
April 3, 1972, and ending April 7, 1972, and for such additional time
in advance thereof to prepare for the trial of cases, and for such fur-
ther time as may be required to complete unfinished business, pur-
suant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered on the minutes of
this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Jus-
tice Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit during the period beginning
April 10, 1972, and ending April 14, 1972, and for such additional
time in advance thereof to prepare for the trial of cases, and for
such further time as may be required to complete unfinished business,
pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered on the minutes
of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, January 24, 1972, until
Tuesday, February 22, 1972.

OPINIONS
No. 71-119. Mike Trbovich, petitioner, v. United Mine Workers
of America et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Case remanded to the
United States District Court for the District of Columbia with direc-
tions to allow limited intervention in accordance with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas dissenting in part. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-5033. Earl A. Love, petitioner, v. The Pullman Company;
and
No. 70-37. United States et al., petitioners, v. The Pullman Com-
pany. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Mr. Justice Powell and
Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of
these cases.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 68–5027. Earnest James Aikens, Jr., petitioner, v. California.
Argued by Mr. Anthony G. Amsterdam for the petitioner and by Mr.
Ronald M. George for the respondent.

MONDAY, JANUARY 17, 1972
319
No. 69-5003. William Henry Furman, petitioner, v. Georgia.
Argued by Mr. Anthony G. Amsterdam for the petitioner and by Mrs.
Dorothy T. Beasley for the respondent.
No. 69-5030. Lucious Jackson, Jr., petitioner, v. Georgia. Argued
by Mr. Jack Greenberg for the petitioner and by Mrs. Dorothy T.
Beasley for the respondent.
No. 69–5031. Elmer Branch, petitioner, v. Texas. Argued by Mr.
Melvyn Carson Bruder for the petitioner and by Mr. Charles Alan
Wright for the respondent.
No. 68–5009. Donald Felix Schneble, petitioner, v. Florida. Argu-
ment commenced by Mr. Clyde B. Wells for the petitioner.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

8mm. Film, et al. Argued by Mr. Solicitor General Erwin N. Griswold

480-278-72-64

MONDAY, JANUARY 24, 1972
322
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice.
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 71–221. Peggy J. Connor et al., appellants, v. John Bell
Williams, Governor of Mississippi, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi. Judg-
ment vacated, except insofar as it applied to the 1971 elections, and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the Southern
District of Mississippi for further proceedings consistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
No. 71-244. In the Matter of Larry Little, petitioner. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Superior Court Division, General Court
of Justice of North Carolina, County of Forsyth. Petition for writ
of certiorari granted, judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
Superior Court Division, General Court of Justice of North Carolina,
County of Forsyth, for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Concurring opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger with whom, Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins.
No. 71–527. United States, appellant, v. Standard Oil Company
of California. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of California. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the United States District Court for the Northern District
of California for further proceedings in conformity wtih the opinion
of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
No. 71-565. United States, appellant, v. Christian Echoes National
Ministry, Inc. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Oklahoma. Judgment vacated and case remanded.
to the United States District Court for the Northern District of Okla-
homa for the entry of a fresh decree, so that the appellant may appeal
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Opinion
480-278-72- -65

MONDAY, JANUARY 24, 1972
323
per curiam. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 71-5431. George Martin Bradley, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eighth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Iowa with directions to dismiss the indictment.
Durham v. United States, 401 U.S. 481 (1971). Opinion per curiam.
The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Blackmun dissent for the reasons
stated in Mr. Justice Blackmun's dissenting opinion in Durham v.
United States, 401 U.S. at 483–485 (1971).
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71–595. Gerald C. Nichol, etc., et al., appellants, v. Alfred L.
Kennan et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Western District of Wisconsin. Judgment affirmed. The Chief Justice,
Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
would dismiss appeal for failure to comply with Rule 13 (1).
No. 71-620. George K. Wyman, etc., appellant, v. Pedro Lopez, etc.,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western
District of New York. Judgment affirmed.
No. 71-679. Daniel Dunn, Director of Welfare, City of New
Haven, et al., appellants, v. Minerva Rivera et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the District of Connecticut. Motion
of appellee Rivera for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Judgment affirmed.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71–5419. Thomas James Piper, Jr., petitioner, v. W. B. Hauck,
Sheriff of Bexar County, Texas, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further consideration in light of Haines v. Kerner, 404
U.S. (1972).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-521. In Matter of Disbarment of Frederick J. Freel. It hav-
ing been reported to the Court that Frederick J. Freel, Esquire, of
Kansas City, Missouri, has been indefinitely suspended from the prac-
tice of law by the Supreme Court of Missouri, duly entered April 15,

MONDAY, JANUARY 24, 1972
324
1971, and this Court by order of November 22, 1971, having suspended
the said Frederick J. Freel from the practice of law in this Court and
directing that a rule issue requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred;
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served upon
the respondent, and that a response has been filed;
It is ordered that the said Frederick J. Freel be, and he is hereby,
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court and that his name be
stricken from roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar
of this Court.
No. A-657. Edwin James Doherty, petitioner, v. United States. The
reapplication for bail is denied.
No. 68–5027. Earnest James Aikens, Jr., petitioner, v. California;
No. 69–5003. William Henry Furman, petitioner, v. Georgia; and
No. 69-5030. Lucious Jackson, Jr., petitioner, v. Georgia. The mo-
tion of the State of Alaska for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
is granted. The motions of the District Attorney for the Eastern Cir-
cuit of Georgia for leave to file briefs, as amicus curiae, in Nos. 69–
5003 and 69–5030 are denied.
No. 70-45. United States, appellant, v. Daniel B. Brewster; and
No. 70-5061. Thomas Kirby, etc., petitioner, v. Illinois. These cases
are restored to the calendar for reargument.
No. 70-5101. John Patler, petitioner, v. Virginia. The renewed
application for bail is denied.
No. 71-600. State Board of Election Commissioners et al., appel-
lants, v. Charles Evers et al.; and
No. 71–650. Minnesota, appellant, v. Northern States Power Com-
pany. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in these cases.
expressing the views of the United States.
No. 71-864. Federal Communications Commission et al., peti-
tioners, v. Business Executives' Move for Vietnam Peace et al. The
application for a stay presented to the Chief Justice, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 71-5144. Edward Lee McNeil, petitioner, v. Director, Pa-
tuxent Institution. The motion of the petitioner for the appointment
of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that E. Barrett Prettyman, Jr.,
Esquire, of Washington, D.C., a member of the Bar of this Court, be,
and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in
this case.

MONDAY, JANUARY 24, 1972
CERTIORARI GRANTED
325
No. 71–224. Harold R. Swenson, Warden, petitioner, v. James
William Stidham. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit granted.
No. 71-496. Clarence Ward, petitioner, v. Village of Monroeville,
Ohio. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio
granted.
No. 71-5139. Gene Ham, petitioner, v. South Carolina. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of South Carolina granted limited to Question
1 presented by the petition which reads as follows:
"1. Whether the trial judge's refusal to examine the jurors on voir
dire as to whether petitioner's race or pre-trial publicity would affect
their ability to render a fair verdict violated petitioner's right to an
impartial jury, guaranteed by the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments
to the Constitution?"
CERTIORARI DENIED

OPINIONS
Geraghty.
No. 70-55. Board of Regents of the University of Texas System,
appellant, v. New Left Education Project et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Western District of Texas.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Western District of Texas with instructions to enter
a fresh decree so that appellant may be able, if it desires, to perfect a
timely appeal. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-72. United States, petitioner, v. Chas. Pfizer & Co., Inc.,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court.
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Tuesday, February 22, 1972, at 10 o'clock.
☑

THURSDAY, JANUARY 27, 1972
337
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall,
Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-760. Bob Bullock, Secretary of State of Texas, petitioner, v.
Dan Weiser et al. The application for a stay of the judgment of the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas pre-
sented to Mr. Justice Powell, and by him referred to the Court, is
granted.
☑
480-278-72-67

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1972
338
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
PER CURIAM OPINIONS
No. 70-5075. Jack Boyd, petitioner, v. A. L. Dutton, Warden. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court
for the Middle District of Georgia for an evidentiary hearing. Opin-
ion per curiam. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom The Chief Justice joins.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom the Chief Jus-
tice and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 71-352. Joseph Colombo, petitioner, v. New York. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals of New York for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-533. Native American Church of Navajoland, Inc. et al.,
appellants, v. Arizona Corporation Commission. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the District of Arizona. Judgment
affirmed. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 71-561. Fred Koehler et al., appellants, v. Richard Ogilvie,
Governor of Illinois, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Illinois. Judgment affirmed.

the Northern District of Illinois. Judgment affirmed.

No. 71–786. Sterner Industries, Inc., appellant, v. United States

No. 71-657. Hawaiian Land Company, Limited, appellant, v.
Director of Taxation, State of Hawaii. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Hawaii. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdic-
tion and set for oral argument.
No. 71-664. Clarence Cloud et al., appellants, v. Merritt S. Deitz
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Kentucky. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would
note probable jurisdiction and set for oral argument.
No. 71-726. Wayne P. Jordan, appellant, v. William D. Meisser
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-767. Alan Kawitt, etc., appellant, v. George A. Mahin,
Director of Revenue of the State of Illinois, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 71-735. Joseph J. Rey, appellant, v. United States. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 71–822. Frank K. King, appellant, v. City of San Bernardino,
etc. et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Ap-
pellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 71-831. Joseph Giordano et al., appellants, v. H. F. Stubbs et
al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 71–838. Phoenix Newspapers, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Wade
Church. Appeal from the Superior Court of Arizona, in and for the
County of Maricopa. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 71-5558. Leon Newsome, appellant, v. New York. Appeal
from the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court of New York, Second
and Eleventh Judicial Districts. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1972
340
No. 71–746. J. W. Hargrove, appellant, v. W. L. Newsome et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Middle Division.
Motion to dispense with printing jurisdictional statement granted. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71–298. Oliver A. Rosengart, petitioner, v. Melvin R. Laird,
Secretary of Defense, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of the suggestions of the
Solicitor General and upon an independent examination of the entire
record. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom The Chief
Justice and Mr. Justice Rehnquist concur.
No. 71-757. Bruce King and Wayne Fisher, petitioners, v. Edwin
W. Jones et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the North-
ern District of Ohio with directions to dismiss the proceedings as
moot.
No. 71-5709. Richard Jimenez, petitioner, v. George J. Beto, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Corrections. Motion for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for Fifth Circuit granted. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration
in light of Haines v. Kerner, 404 U.S.— (1972).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-520. In Matter of Disbarment of Franklin P. Samples.
It having been reported to the Court that Franklin P. Samples of
Huntsville, Alabama, has been disbarred from the practice of law by
the Supreme Court of Alabama, duly entered September 1, 1971, and
this Court by order of November 22, 1971, having suspended the said
Franklin P. Samples from the practice of law in this Court and direct-
ing that a rule issue requiring him to show cause why he should not
be disbarred;
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served upon
the respondent, and that the time within which to file a return to
the rule has expired;
It is ordered that the said Franklin P. Samples be, and he is hereby
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court and that his name be

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1972
341
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the
Bar of this Court.
No. A-771. Sam A. Pesoli et al., petitioners, v. Morgan F. Murphy
et al. The application for a temporary injunction presented to Mr.
Justice Rehnquist, and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that the application should be
granted as to petitioner Pesoli, he having been suspended solely on the
ground that he invoked the self-incrimination clause of the Fifth
Amendment.
No. A-775. Camilo Culado, petitioner, v. United States The ap-
plication for stay of the mandate presented to Mr. Justice Douglas,
and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-816. Bob Bullock, Secretary of State of Texas, appellant, v.
Dan Weiser et al. The motion of appellees to advance and expedite and
to dispense with printing is denied.
No. A-822. Richard Dean Thorbus, appellant, v. George J. Beto,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The application for bail
presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the Court,
is denied.
No. A-838. Barbara J. Woodsum, appeallant, v. James H. Boyd et
al. The application for a stay order presented to Mr. Justice Powell,
and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 69-5003. William Henry Furman, petitioner, v. Georgia; and
No. 69-5030. Lucious Jackson, Jr., petitioner, v. Georgia. The
motion of respondent for leave to file a supplemental brief, after
argument, is granted.
No. 70-75. Moose Lodge No. 107, appellant, v. K. Leroy Irvis et al.
The motion of the Attorney General of Pennsylvania for leave to
participate in oral argument is denied.
No. 70-5015. Jon Richard Argersinger, petitioner, v. Raymond
Hamlin, Sheriff, Leon County, Florida. The motion of the Solicitor
General for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is
granted and a total of 20 minutes is allotted for that purpose.
No. 70-5112. Willie Mae Weber, petitioner, v. Aetna Casualty &
Surety Company et al. The motion of the American Civil Liberties
Union for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No 70-5276. Albert Delanor Murel et al., petitioners, v. Baltimore
City Criminal Court et al. The motion of petitioners for additional
time for oral argument is denied. Mr. Justice Stewart is of the opinion
that the motion should be granted. The motion for additional counsel
to argue on behalf of petitioners is granted.

petitioner is granted.

Warden;

No. 71-5380. Pae Galdeira and The Hawaiians, petitioners, v.
William S. Richardson et al.;
No. 71-5394.
Corporation;
Donald W. Shappell, petitioner, v. Martin-Marietta
No. 71-5479. John Todaro, petitioner, v. United States;
No 71-5482. Edward McCray, petitioner, v. United States Mar-
shall for the District of Kansas et al.; and
No. 71-5524. Howard Allen Logan, petitioner, v. Superintendent,
Wallkill Prison. Petitions for rehearing denied.
No. 70-38. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Florida
Power & Light Company. Petition for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice
Stewart took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 70–193. Leonard Russo, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice White took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this petition.
No. 70-5025. Francis Haines, petitioner, 2. Otto J. Kerner, For-
mer Governor, State of Illinois, et al. Petition for rehearing denied.
Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this petition.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1972
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
363
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit during the period beginning March
13, 1972, and ending March 15, 1972, and for such additional time in
advance thereof to prepare for the trial of cases, and for such further
time as may be required to complete unfinished business, pursuant
to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered on the minutes of this Court,
pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

ADMISSIONS TO THE BAR ON ORAL MOTIONS
Applicant
City and State

W. Anthony Park

Boise, Idaho

William Bradford
Reynolds.
OPINIONS
No. 70-28. United States, petitioner, v. Edna Generes, wife of, and
Allen H. Generes. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals with directions that judgment be entered for
the United States. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Separate opinion
by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins as to
Parts I, II, and III of the Court's opinion and its judgment of
reversal. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-267. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Robert
Scrivener, dba AA Electric Company. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun.
No. 70-5045. Donald Lindsay et al, appellants, v. Dorothea M.
Norman et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Oregon. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the District
of Oregon for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas dissenting in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan dissenting
in part. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
480-278-72–
-74

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1972
381
No. 70-66. Richard L. Roudebush, appellant, v. R. Vance Hartke
et al.; and
No. 70-67. Theodore L. Sendak, Attorney General of Indiana, ap-
pellant, v. R. Vance Hartke et al. Appeals from the United States
District Court for the Southern District of Indiana. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Indiana for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins
dissenting in part. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took
no part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 70-91. Joseph Parisi, petitioner, v. Philip B. Davidson, etc.,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas concurring in the result. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-5122. Dennis Stephen Duncan, petitioner, v. Tennessee.
On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Middle Divi-
sion. Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion
per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr.
Justice Marshall join.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 70-85. Paul M. Branzburg, petitioner, v. John P. Hayes, Judge,
etc., et al. One and one-half hours allowed for oral argument. Argued
by Mr. Edgar A. Zingman for the petitioner, by Mr. Edwin A.
Schroering, Jr., for the respondents, and by Mr. William Bradford
Reynolds for the United States, as amicus curiae, by special leave of
Court.
No. 70-94. In the Matter of Paul Pappas, petitioner. One and one-
half hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. E. Barrett Pret-
tyman, Jr., for the petitioner, by Mr. Joseph J. Hurley for the
respondent, and by Mr. William Bradford Reynolds for the United
States, as amicus curiae, by special leave of Court.
No. 70-99. Evansville-Vanderburgh Airport Authority District
et al., petitioners, v. Delta Airlines, Inc., et al. Argument commenced.
by Mr. Howard P. Trockman for the petitioners.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-

OPINIONS
No. 69–5. D. H. Overmyer Co., Inc. of Ohio, et al., petitioners, v.
Frick Company. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of
Ohio, Lucas County. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom
Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-6. Nellie Swarb et al., appellants, v. William M. Lennox
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed. Stay heretofore granted
by Circuit Justice dissolved. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Doug-
las dissenting in part. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-5030. Margaret Papachristou et al., petitioners, v. City of
Jacksonville. On writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of
Florida, First District. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District, for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70–5055. Raymond Smith and Melvin McClain, petitioners,
v. Florida. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Florida
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-128. Bob Bullock et al., appellants, v. Van Phillip Carter
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Texas. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-29. John Giglio, petitioner, v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.

THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1972
383
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr.
Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 70-161. Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Health, Education
and Welfare, appellant, v. Radie Wright et al.; and
No. 70-5211. Radie Wright et al., appellants, v. Elliott L. Rich-
ardson, etc. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia. Judgment vacated and cases remanded to the
United States District Court for the District of Columbia with
directions to remand the cases to the Secretary of Health, Education
and Welfare and to retain jurisdiction for such further proceedings,
if any, as may be necessary upon completion of the administrative
procedure. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr.
Justice Marshall join.

Mallory, Jr., for the appellants and by Mr. W. Michael Dunn for the

Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, Southern Division, et al.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1972
384
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White Mr. Justice Marshall,
Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-56. John J. Gilligan et al., appellants, v. Helen Marcia
Sweetenham et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Southern District of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed as moot.
No. 71-765. Northern Natural Gas Company, appellant, v. Doro-
thy Wilson et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Kansas. Judgment affirmed.
No. 71-828. Detroit Police Officers Association et al., appellants, v.
City of Detroit, Michigan. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Michi-
gan. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-855. Edwin O. Willis, appellant, v. State Board of Control,
State of California, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Cali-
fornia Fourth Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-880. Edwin Ray Haynes et al., appellants, v. Clifford
Eugene Linder et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Missouri. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied.
No. 71-5464. Forrest L. Kirk, appellant, v. Lewis C. McMeen,
Iowa County Attorney, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Iowa. Judgment affirmed. Mr.
Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 71-5743. Roberto Torres and Walter Dinger, appellants, v.
New York State Department of Labor et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Southern District of New York. Judg-
ment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction and reverse. Gold-
berg v. Kelly, 397 U.S. 254 (1970).
480-278-72–76

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1972
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
385
No. A-871. Fraser & Johnston Company, petitioner, v. Lodge 1327,
International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers,
AFL-CIO. The application for a stay presented to Mr. Justice Doug-
las, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 40, Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, plaintiff v.
State of New York et al. The motion of the American Express Com-
pany for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 70-74. Pipefitters Local Union No. 562 et al., petitioners, v.
United States. The motion of the petitioners for leave to file a sup-
plemental brief, after argument, is granted. Mr. Justice Blackmun
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 70-220. Mortimer M. Caplin, etc., petitioner, v. The Marine
Midland Grace Trust Company of New York. The motion of the Solici-
tor General for leave to participate in oral argument on behalf of the
Securities and Exchange Commission is granted and a total of 15 min-
utes allotted for that purpose. Counsel for the respondent allotted 15
additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 70–250. Robert B. Carleson et al., appellants, v. Nancy Remil-
lard, etc., et al. That motion of appellee Remillard for appointment
of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Carmen L. Massey, Esquire,
of Richmond, California, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as
counsel for appellee Remillard in this case.
No. 70-5015. Jon Richard Argersinger, petitioner, v. Raymond
Hamlin, Sheriff, Leon County, Florida. The motion for leave to cite
supplemental authority is granted.
No. 70–5061. Thomas Kirby, etc., petitioner, v. Illinois. The mo-
tion of the Attorney General of California for leave to participate in
oral argument, as amicus curiae, is granted and a total of 15 minutes
allotted for that purpose. Counsel for the petitioner allotted 15 addi-
tional minutes for oral argument.
No. 70-5276. Albert Delanor Murel et al., petitioners, v. Balti-
more City Criminal Court et al. The motion to dispense with printing
the amicus curiae brief of the Prison Research Council of the Uni-
versity of Pennsylvania Law School is granted.
No. 71–994. Myron Epstein, petitioner, v. The Association of the
Bar of the City of New York. The application for a stay presented to
Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Blackmun are of the opinion that
application should be granted.
No. 71-5097. Harold Eugene Huffman, petitioner, v. Faye I. Boer-
sen. The motion of the respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1972
386
No. 71-5103. John J. Morrissey and G. Donald Booher, petitioners,
v. Lou V. Brewer, Warden, et al. The motion to dispense with printing
the amicus curiae brief of James H. Russell is granted.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 71-873. United States, appellant, v. Falstaff Brewing Corpo-
ration et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of Rhode Island. In this case probable jurisdiction noted and case
set for oral argument with No. 71–703.
No. 71-879. Heublein, Inc., appellant, v. South Carolina Tax Com-
mission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Carolina. In this
case probable jurisdiction noted.

thaniel Biggers. Motion to use record in No. 237, October Term, 1967

Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of these motions and petition.

Ninth Circuit granted.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1972
387
No. 71-865. Post-Newsweek Stations, Capital Area, Inc., peti-
tioner, v. Business Executives' Move for Vietnam Peace; and
No. 71–866. American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., petitioner,
v. Democratic National Committee. Petitions for writs of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit granted. Cases consolidated and a total of two hours allotted
for oral argument. The mandate of the United States Court of Appeals
for the District of Columbia Circuit issued on October 29, 1971, in
theses cases is hereby recalled and stayed pending the sending down of
the judgment of this Court. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
the stay should be denied.
CERTIORARI DENIED

Gates, Chairman, Connecticut Board of Parole, et al. Petition for writ

cuit denied.
