No. 71-486. Dennis Gary Monger, petitioner, v. Florida. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied, it
appearing that the judgment of the Supreme Court of Florida rests
upon an adequate state ground. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stewart
concur.
No. 71-554. Dennis L. Liepman, petitioner, v. California. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Sec-
ond Appellate District, denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion
that certiorari should be granted.

tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should
be granted.

et al. Motion to dispense with printing petition and motion of re-
spondents to dispense with printing brief in opposition granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 71-720. John Philip Cerone, Sr., and James Cerone, peti-
tioners, v. United States;
No. 71-759. Donald J. Angelini, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 71-760. Dominic Cortina, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted for the reasons stated in his dissent in
Addonizio v. United States, 405, U.S. — (1972).

for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois denied, it ap-
pearing that the judgment of the Supreme Court of Illinois rests upon

for the Western District of Oklahoma, petitioner, v. William H. Pat
O'Bryan. Petititon for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the

no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

for the District of Columbia Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and

granted.

RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, March 6, 1972, until
Monday, March 20, 1972.

OPINIONS
No. 70-49. Hawaii, petitioner, v. Standard Oil Company of Cali-
fornia et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Doug-
las joins. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-70. Federal Trade Commission, petitioner, v. The Sperry
and Hutchinson Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed and modi-
fied to the extent that the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals
with instructions to return case to the Federal Trade Commission for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

480 278-72-— 81

MONDAY, MARCH 6, 1972
406
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-291. Louis H. Osmond et al., appellants, v. Ernest S.
Spence et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Delaware. Motion to dispense with printing jurisdictional
statement granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of Delaware for further con-
sideration in light of Swarb v. Lennox, 405 U.S.
Overmyer Co., Inc., of Ohio v. Frick Co., 405 U.S. (1972). The
order of June 21, 1971, entered by Mr. Justice Brennan, as modified
by his order of August 20, 1971, shall continue in effect unless and
until superseded by order of the District Court.
-
(1972) and D. H.
No. 71-624. Joseph R. Thompson, appellant, v. Joan Thompson.
Appeal from the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District.
Motion of the appellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied.
No. 71–805. The Philada Home Fund, Inc., appellant, v. Board of
Review, Ohio Bureau of Employment Services. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 71-5773. Jim Fair, appellant, v. H. L. Wiggins. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 71–929. Wendy Forbush, on behalf of herself and others simi-
larly situated, appellant, v. George C. Wallace, Individually and as
Governor of Alabama, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Middle District of Alabama. Judgment affirmed.
480-278-72-82

MONDAY, MARCH 6, 1972
407
No. 71-932. Minnie Ruhl Woods, et al., appellants, v. The Society
for the Propagation of the Faith of the Archdiocese of New Orleans,
Inc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-5262. Virginia M. Carpenter et al., appellants, v. William
R. Sterrett el al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Northern District of Indiana. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Northern District of Indiana for further
consideration in light of Townsend v. Swank and Alexander v. Swank,
404 U.S. 282 (1972).
No. 71–5806. Janet L. Charleston et al., appellants, v. Helene
Wohlgemuth et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be
noted and case set for oral argument.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 71-41. International Union of Operating Engineers, Local
150, AFL-CIO, petitioner, v. Flair Builders, Inc. The request for
additional time for filing brief for the respondent is granted and 30
additional days are allotted for that purpose. Typewritten briefs may
be filed in lieu of printed briefs. J. Robert Murphy, Esquire, of
Aurora, Illinois, is invited to file a brief and argue in this case, as
amicus curiae, in support of the judgment below.
No. 71–709. Masaru Sumida et al., petitioners, v. Fusao Yumen
et al. The motion to disbar is denied.
No. 71-1017. Mike Gravel, United States Senator, petitioner, v.
United States; and
No. 70–1026. United States, petitioner, v. Mike Gravel, United
States Senator. The motion to expedite is granted so that the con-
solidated cases may be briefed and argued during the present term of
Court. The motion of The Unitarian Universalist Association for leave
to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, in No. 71-1017 is
denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 71-909. Environmental Protection Agency et al., petitioners,
v. Patsy T. Mink et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit granted.
No. 71-839. Paul P. Erlenbaugh et al., petitioners, v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted limited to Question 1, pre-
sented by the petition which reads as follows:

1
MONDAY, MARCH 6, 1972
408
"1. Whether the Court of Appeals erred in not following the opin-
ion of the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in a 1967 case en-
titled U.S. v. Arnold, 380 Federal 2nd, 366, thus creating a conflict
between the circuits." Mr. Justice White took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this petition.
No. 71-1016. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Louisiana
Power & Light Company et al.; and
No. 71-1040. United Gas Pipe Line Company et al., petitioners,
v. Louisiana Power & Light Company et al. Petitions for writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
granted and cases consolidated and a total of one hour is allowed
for oral argument to review the judgment of the Court of Ap-
peals in Federal Power Commissioner v. Louisiana Power & Light
Co., et al. (No. 71-2550). Petitions for writs of certiorari before judg-
ment to review the opinion and order of the Federal Power Commis-
sion (FPC opinion 606) denied. Motion to expedite granted so that
the consolidated cases may be briefed and argued during the present
term of Court. Motion of the Humble Oil & Refining Company for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of the State of
Louisiana et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
these petitions and motions.
CERTIORARI DENIED

No. 71-5421. Cuthbert McInnies Midgett, petitioner, v. A. E.
Slayton, Jr., Superintendent, Virginia State Penitentiary. The order
of this Court heretofore entered on February 22, 1972, in this case is
hereby revoked. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit dismissed.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 71–665. Mary Vasquez and Lydia Borrego, petitioners, v.
John J. Walsh, Warden. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of
habeas corpus denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 71–5791. Lawrence Cleaves, petitioner, v. Pennsylvania et al.;
No. 71–5792. William L. Knight, petitioner, v. United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Motions for
leave to file petitions for writs of mandamus denied.
No. 71-812. Jerome H. Lemelson, petitioner, v. Raymond J. Pet-
tine, Chief Judge of the United States District Court for the District
of Rhode Island. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of mandamus
and/or prohibition denied.

MONDAY, MARCH 6, 1972
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF PROHIBITION DENIED
414
No. 71-5812. Ruchell Magee, petitioner, v. Louis S. Nelson et al.
Motion for leave to file petition for writ of prohibition denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 1469, October Term, 1970. Homart Development Co., peti-
tioner, v. Roger Jon Diamond et al. Joint motion for leave to file
petition for rehearing denied. The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice
Blackmum are of the opinion that the motion should be granted.
No. 71-437. Myron M. Amato and Jack L. Rockey, petitioners,
v. Wisconsin;
No. 71-5504. Edward D. Feurtado, petitioner, v. Florida; and
No. 71-5536. Lee Odith Wickline, petitioner, v. W. A. Brooks, etc.,
et al. Petitions for rehearing denied.
ORDER
It is ordered that Michael Rodak, Jr., be appointed Clerk of this
Court to succeed E. Robert Seaver effective at the commencement of
business March 4, 1972, and that he take the oath of office and give
bond as required by statute and the order of this Court entered Novem-
ber 22, 1948.

MONDAY, MARCH 6, 1972
OPINIONS
418
No. 70-52. United States, petitioner, v. Mississippi Chemical
Corporation et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals with direction that the judgment be entered
for the United States. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice
Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-5038. John Adams, petitioner, v. Illinois. On writ of cer-
teriorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment affirmed. Mr.
Justice Brennan announced the judgment of the Court and delivered
an opinion in which Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice White join.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in the result. Con-
curring statement by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Mr. Justice
Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, March 20, 1972, at 10 o'clock.

FRIDAY, MARCH 17, 1972
419
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
ORDER IN PENDING CASES
No. 71-1170. WHDH, Inc., petitioner, v. United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit; and
No. 71–1171. WHDH, Inc., petitioner, v. Federal Communica-
tions Commission, et al. The application for a stay pending action on
the petition for writ of certiorari and the motion for leave to file
petition for writ of mandamus presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and
by him referred to the Court, is denied. The Chief Justice took no
part in the consideration or decision of this application.

480-278-72-84

MONDAY, MARCH 20, 1972
420
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 71-5552. Fred A. Cruz, petitioner, v. George J. Beto, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Corrections. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas for
a hearing and appropriate findings. Opinion per curiam. The Chief
Justice joins in the result. Mr. Justice Blackmun concurs in the result.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-675. Christopher Kappos, appellant, v. Iowa. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Iowa. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted.
No. 71-936. Barbara Manard et al., apellants, v. Andrew P. Mil-
ler, Attorney General, Commonwealth of Virginia, et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.
Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable
jurisdiction should be noted.
No. 71-5399. Albert Lee Perryman, appellant, v. Washington.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washington. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 71-5590. Robert Clayton Salisbury, appellant, v. Oregon. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeals of Oregon. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

MONDAY, MARCH 20, 1972
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
421
No. 71-431. Immigration and Naturalization Service, petitioner,
v. Jovenica Arce Vitales. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals with directions to dismiss the peti-
tion to review the order of deportation.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-880. Michael J. Shelton, petitioner, v. Carl L. Brunson, etc.,
et al. The application for a stay of deployment presented to Mr. Justice
Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas would continue the stay pending the timely filing and disposi-
tion of a petition for writ of certiorari in this Court.
No. A-905. Edward M. Davis, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Cinema
Classics, Ltd., Inc., et al.; and
No. A-913. Joseph P. Busch, Jr., et al., petitioners, v. Cinema
Classics, Ltd., Inc., et al. The applications for a stay of the preliminary
injunction presented to Mr. Justice Powell, and by him referred to the
Court, are denied.
No. A-926. John Doe, In the Matter of the Grand Jury testimony
and Contempt of Cynthia B. Schwartz, petitioner, v. United States.
The application for a stay of the execution of sentence for civil con-
tempt presented to Mr. Justice Marshall, and by him referred to the
Court, is granted pending further order of this Court.
No. A-962. California, petitioner, v. Robert Page Anderson. The
application of the State of California for a stay of the judgment of
the Supreme Court of California (Crim 13617) is denied.
No. 50, Original. State of Vermont, plaintiff, v. State of New
York et al. The motion of the Monroe County Conservation Council
for leave to intervene as a party plaintiff is denied.
No. 54, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. States of Florida and
Texas. The motion for leave to file a bill of complaint is granted and
the defendants are allotted sixty days to answer.
No. 70-283. Frederick E. Adams, Warden, petitioner, v. Robert
Williams. The motion of District Attorney of New York County for
leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 71-110. David Gelbard and Sidney Parnas, petitioners, v.
United States. The motion of petitioner Gelbard for assignment of
a separate docket number and/or additional time for oral argument
is denied.

MONDAY, MARCH 20, 1972
422
No. 71–263. United States, petitioner, v. Jogues Egan and Anne
Elizabeth Walsh. The motion of Ramsey Clark and Leonard B.
Boudin to permit Jack J. Levine to argue orally, pro hac vice, on
behalf of respondent Egan is granted.
No. 71–288. Melvin R. Laird, Secretary of Defense, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Arlo Tatum et al. The motion of Sam J. Ervin, Jr., for
additional time to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae,
is denied. Permission for two counsel to argue on behalf of the re-
spondents is granted.
No. 71-315. Deepsouth Packing Co., Inc., petitioner, v. The Lai-
tram Corporation. The motion of Edward S. Irons et al., for leave
to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
No. 71–708. Paul J. Tafficante et al., petitioners, v. Metropolitan
Life Insurance Company et al. The motion of petitioners to dispense
with printing briefs and appendix is granted.
No. 71-858. Thomas Ricci, petitioner, v. Chicago Mercantile Ex-
change et al. The motion for reconsideration of the petition for
certiorari is denied.
No. 71–1024. Sixty-Seventh Minnesota State Senate, appellant,
v. Richard A. Beens et al.; and
No. 71-1145. Sixty-Seventh Minnesota State Senate, appellant,
v. Richard A. Beens et al. The motion to expedite is denied. The cases
are hereby consolidated.
No. 71-1128. Vladislav Kelemen et al., petitioners, v. Serbian
Orthodox Church Congregation of St. Demetrius of Akron, Ohio. The
motion for consolidation with Nos. 71-563 and 71-867 is denied.
No. 71-5255. Willie Mae Barker, petitioner, v. John W. Wingo,
Warden. The motion of The Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights
Under Law for leave to file a brief, as amicus cumiae, is granted. The
motion of M. Curran Clem to permit Robert W. Willmott, Jr., for-
leave to argue orally, pro hac vice, on behalf of the respondent is
granted.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED

of New York, et al., appellants, v. James Royster et al. Apppeal from
the United States District Court for the Southern District of New
York. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 71–862. United Air Lines, Inc., appellant, v. George E. Mahin
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. In this case prob-
able jurisdiction noted.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Customs and Patent Appeals during the period beginning May 1,
1972, and ending May 5, 1972, and for such further time as may be
required to complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C.
§ 294 (a), is ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to
28 U.S.C. § 295.
ORDER
An order is entered approving the bond of the Clerk of this Court
and directing that it be recorded.

MONDAY, MARCH 20, 1972
OPINIONS
443
No. 71–247. William Rabe, petitioner, v. Washington. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Washington. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Washington for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist
joins.
No. 70-5344. Lorenzo Willis, etc., petitioner, v. Prudential Insur-
ance Company of America. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Georgia. Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court.
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 71-32. Curtis C. Flood, petitioner, v. Bowie K. Kuhn et al.
Argued by Mr. Arthur J. Goldberg for the petitioner, by Mr. Paul A.
Porter for respondent Bowie K. Kuhn and by Mr. Louis L. Hoynes,
Jr., for other respondents.
No. 70-45. United States, appellant, v. Daniel B. Brewster. Re-
argued by Mr. Solicitor General Erwin N. Griswold for the appellant
and by Mr. Norman P. Ramsey for the appellee.
No. 70–88. S&E Contractors, Inc., petitioner, v. United States. Re-
argued by Mr. Geoffrey Creyke, Jr., for the petitioner and by Mr.
Irving Jaffe for the respondent.
No. 70–5061. Thomas Kirby, etc., petitioner, v. Illinois. One and
one-half hours allowed for reargument. Reargument commenced by
Mr. Jerold S. Solovy for the petitioner.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

No. 68-5009. Donald Felix Schneble, petitioner, v. Florida. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan
join.
No. 70-305. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, petitioner, v. First
Security Bank of Utah, N. A., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr.
Justice White joins.
No.70-58. Oliver T. Fein, petitioner, v. Selective Service System
Local Board No. 7, Yonkers, N.Y., et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with
whom Mr. Justice Stewart joins. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-13. Winfield Dunn, Governor of the State of Tennessee,
et al., appellants, v. James F. Blumstein. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.

MONDAY, MARCH 27, 1972
451
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr.
Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
☐ Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-600. State Board of Election Commissioners, et al., appel-
lants, v. Charles Evers et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Southern District of Mississippi. The appeal is dis-
missed for failure to docket the case within the time prescribed by
Rule 13 (1). Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom
Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
No. 71-891. Capital Broadcasting Co., et al., appellants, v. Acting
Attorney General of the United States et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of Columbia. The motion of
John F. Banzhaf III et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae,
and to dispense with printing is granted. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan are of the opinion that probable
jurisdiction should be noted. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion or appeal.
No. 71-919. National Association of Broadcasters et al., appel-
lants, v. Acting Attorney General of the United States et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of Columbia.
Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan are
of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted.
No. 71-1003. Horse Creek Royalty Corp. et al., appellants, v.
Southland Company et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Wyoming. The appeal is dismissed for want of a properly presented
federal question.
No. 71–1030. Edward Kiernan et al., appellants, v. John V. Lind-
say, as Mayor of the City of New York, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Southern District of New York. Judg-
480-278-72-92

MONDAY, MARCH 27, 1972
452
ment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable
jurisdiction should be noted.
No. 71-5915. Charles Strickland, a minor, etc., et al., appellants, v.
Board of Education, San Francisco Unified School District, et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 71-5948. Isaac Presler, appellant, v. State Division of Human
Rights et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70–251. Lionel Adolph Joseph, petitioner, v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for consideration in light of the position now asserted by
the Solicitor General. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with
whom Mr. Justice Marshall concurs.
No. 70-5056. Peter St. Clair, petitioner, v. Selective Service Local
Board No. 35 in Brooklyn, New York, et al. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cir-
cuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of Fein v.
Selective Service System Local Board No. 7, Yonkers, N. Y. et al., 405
U.S. — (1972). Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 71-316. Elliot Laurence Blatt, petitioner, v. Local Board No.
116 Fredericksburg City Selective Service System et al. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further con-
sideration in light of Fein v. Selective Service System Local Board No.
7, Yonkers, N. Y., et. al., 405 U. S. (1972). Mr. Justice Powell and
Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
-
No. 71-448. Russell M. Morgan, petitioner, v. Bert Melchar et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals of the Third Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further consideration in light of Fein v. Selective Service System Local

| SUPPLEMENTAL
MONDAY, MARCH 27, 1972
-
453
Board No. 7, Yonkers, N.Y., et al., 405 U.S. — (1972). Mr. Justice
Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 71-5840. Leslie John Lenhard, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted,
judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for con-
sideration in light of the position now asserted by the Solicitor
General.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-986. Washington State Labor Council, AFL-CIO, peti-
tioner, v. Gilbert H. Jertberg et al., Judges of Three Judge Court, et
al. The application for a temporary stay presented to Mr. Justice
Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 40, Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, plaintiff, v.
State of New York et al. The motion of the State of Pennsylvania for
additional time for oral argument is granted, and a total of 45 minutes
is allotted to each side for oral argument, the time to be allocated by
the parties.
No. 45, Original. State of Washington et al., plaintiffs, v. General
Motors Corporation et al. The motion of the plaintiffs for leave to file
a brief, after argument, is granted.
No. 71-492. Lloyd Corporation, Ltd., petitioner, v. Donald M.
Tanner et al. The motions of the Homart Development Co.; and the
American Retail Federation for leave to file briefs, as amicus curiae,
are granted. The motion of the Homart Development Co. for leave to
participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 71-506. United States et al., petitioners, v. Midwest Video
Corporation. The motion of the State of Illinois for leave to participate
in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 71-1016. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Louisiana
Power & Light Company et al.; and
No. 71-1040. United Gas Pipe Line Company et al., petitioners, v.
Louisiana Power & Light Company et al. The motions of The Brooklyn
Union Gas Company; the Public Service Commission for the State of
New York; The Columbia Gas Transmission Corp.; and Pipeline
Intervenors for leave to file briefs, as amicus curiae, are granted.

No. 71-558. Louis A. Heyd, Jr., Sheriff, Parish of Orleans, Lou-
isiana, petitioner, v. Leonard Bastida. Motion of the respondent for

denied.
No. 71-605. Aaron Henry et al., petitioners, v. Claiborne Hard-
ware Company et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted. Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 71-615. Paul Chapman, petitioner, v. California. It appear-
ing the state court decision is not final, petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District,
denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall concur.
No. 71-806. John W. Wehinger, petitioner, v. California. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First
Appellate District, denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion
that certiorari should be granted.
No. 71–816. Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., petitioner, v. Kansas Elec-
tric Supply Company, Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.

States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the
opinion that certiorari should be granted.

for the Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that.
certiorari should be granted.

v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States

opinion that certiorari should be granted.

REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 70-161. Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Health, Educa-
cation and Welfare, appellant, v. Radie Wright et al.; and
No. 70-5211. Radie Wright et al., appellants, v. Elliott L. Richard-
son, etc.;

and Allen H. Generes. Petition for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice

or decision of this petition.
No. 70-267. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Robert
Scrivener, dba AA Electric Company. Motion to dispense with print-
ing granted. Motion to dispense with taxation of costs granted. Peti-
tion for rehearing denied.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Southern District of Texas during the period be-
ginning November 1, 1972, and ending December 31, 1972, and for such
additional time in advance thereof to prepare for the trial of cases, and
for such further time, as may be required to complete unfinished busi-
ness pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered on the minutes
of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 3, 1972, until Mon-
day, April 10, 1972.

465
No. 71–227. United States et al., appellants, v. Allegheny-Ludlum
Steel Corporation et al. Argued by Mr. Samuel Huntington for the
Appellants and by Mr. Max O. Truitt, Jr., and Mr. William M.
Moloney for the appellees.

tioners, v. Arlo Tatum et al. Argued by Mr. Solicitor General Erwin
N. Griswold for the petitioners, by Mr. Frank Askin for the respond-
ents and by Mr. Sam J. Ervin, Jr., for the Unitarian Universalist
Ass'n et al., as amici curiae.
No. 71-110. David Gelbard and Sidney Parnas, petitioners, v.
United States. Argued by Mr. Michael E. Tigar for the petitioners and
by Mr. Daniel M. Friedman for the respondent.

Elizabeth Walsh. Argued by Mr. Daniel M. Friedman for the peti-
tioner and by Mr. Jack J. Levine for the respondents, pro hac vice, by
special leave of Court.

OPINIONS
No. 70-82. United States, appellant, v. Topco Associates, Inc. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the Northern District
of Illinois. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Illinois for the entry of an
appropriate decree. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun concurring in the result. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-113. Ford Motor Company, appellant, v. United States et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of Michigan. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in the result. Opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in part and dissenting in part.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in part and dissenting in
part. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.

City Criminal Court et al. Argument continued by Mr. Henry R. Lord

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-16. Glenda M. Cocanower, appellant, v. Paul N. Marston,
Individually and as Recorder for Maricopa County, et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the District of Arizona. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
District of Arizona for further consideration in light of Dunn v.
Blumstein, 405 U.S.- (1972).
No. 70-81. Mary Fitzpatrick et al., appellants, v. Board of Election
Commissioners of the City of Chicago et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Illinois for further consideration in light of
Dunn v. Blumstein, 405 U.S. — (1972).
No. 70-5076. Robert L. Lester et al., appellants, v. Board of Elec-
tions for the District of Columbia et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court of the District of Columbia. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia for further consideration in light of Dunn v. Blumstein, 405
U.S. (1972).
-
No. 71-5690. James Earl Ferguson et al., appellants, v. John Bell
Williams, Governor, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Mississippi. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the United States District for the Northern District
of Mississippi for further consideration in light of Dunn v. Blumstein,
405 U.S. (1972).
No. 70-20. James E. Canniffe et al., appellants, v. Harvey M. Burg.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Massachusetts. Judgment affirmed.
No. 70-80. Deane Davis, Governor of the State of Vermont, et al.,
appellants, v. Richard S. Kohn et ux. Appeal from the United States
District Court of the District of Vermont. Judgment affirmed.
480-278-72-96

MONDAY, APRIL 3, 1972
470
No. 71-628. Caroline B. Cody, etc., et al., appellants, v. Thomas J.
Andrews et ux. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Middle District of North Carolina. Judgment affirmed.
No. 70-76. Joseph L. Donovan, Secretary of the State of Minne-
sota, et al., appellants, v. William J. Keppel et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the District of Minnesota. Judgment
affirmed. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or
decision of this appeal.
No. 70-51. Edgar D. Whitcomb, Governor of Indiana, etc., et al.,
appellants v. Don Affeldt et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Indiana. Motion of appellees for
leave to dispense with printing granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 70-59. Mabel S. Amos, Secretary of State of Alabama, et al.
appellants, v. Sallie M. Hadnott et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Middle District of Alabama. Motion of appellees
for leave to dispense with printing granted. Motion of appellants for
leave to dispense with printing jurisdictional statement granted.
Judgment affirmed.
No. 70–68. Virginia State Board of Elections, appellant, v. John
Bufford et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Virginia. Motion of appellees for leave to dispense
with printing granted. Judgment afirmed.
No. 71–650. Minnesota, appellant, v. Northern States Power Com-
pany. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Stewart dissent from the affirmance.
No. 71-674. Lake Shore Auto Parts Co., appellant, v. Bernard J.
Korzen, County Treasurer and Ex-Officio County Collector of Cook
County, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 71-1001. Aram K. Berberian, appellant, v. Rhode Island.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Rhode Island. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 71-950. Garrett Freightlines, Inc., appellant, v. United States
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Colorado. The appeal is dismissed. Shenandoah Valley Broadcasting,
Inc. v. American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, 375
U.S. 39 (1963). Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from the dismissal and
would affirm, believing that the appeal is properly taken.

MONDAY, APRIL 3, 1972
471
No. 71–1039. D. A. Anderson et al., appellants, v. Robert S. Cal-
vert, Comptroller of Public Accounts of the State of Texas, et al.
Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Third Supreme
Judicial District. Motion of appellants for leave to dispense with
printing reply brief granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-5080. Joseph Wayne Weddle, petitioner, v. Director, Pa-
tuxent Institution, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of Lynch v. Household Finance
Corp., 405 U.S. - (1972).
No. 70-5395. Annie Mae Roberts et al., petitioners, v. John
Harder, Commissioner of Welfare of the State of Connecticut. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of
Lynch v. Household Finance Corp., 405 U.S. — (1972).
-
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-974. In Matter of Resignation of Albert B. Gerber. Albert
B. Gerber, of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, having resigned as a
member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice.
No. 70-223. Central Hardware Company, petitioner, v. National
Labor Relations Board et al. The motion of the respondent, Retail
Clerks Union, for additional time for oral argument is granted and
10 minutes are allotted for that purpose. The petitioner is also allotted
10 additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 70-283. Frederick E. Adams, Warden, petitioner, v. Robert
Williams. The motion of the American Civil Liberties Union for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 71-452. Catherine J. Healy et al., petitioners, v. F. Don James
et al. The motion of the Associated Students of San Francisco State
College et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is denied.
No. 71-492. Lloyd Corporation, Ltd., petitioner, v. Donald M.
Tanner et al. The motion of The American Retail Federation for leave
to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.

MONDAY, APRIL 3, 1972
472
No. 71-857. EVCO, dba EVCO Instructional Designs, petitioner,
v. Franklin Jones, Commissioner of the Bureau of Revenue of the State
of New Mexico, et al. The motion of the petitioner to dispense with
printing the appendix and to proceed on the original record is granted.
No. 71-1016. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Louisiana
Power & Light Company et al.; and
No. 71-1040. United Gas Pipe Line Company et al., petitioners, v.
Louisiana Power & Light Company et al. The motion of Mobile Gas
Service Corporation et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is
granted. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this motion.
No. 70-1017. Mike Gravel, United States Senator, petitioner, v.
United States; and
No. 70-1026. United States, petitioner, v. Mike Gravel, United
States Senator. The motion of counsel for Gravel for additional time
for oral argument is denied. The motion of the United States Senate
for leave to permit Sam J. Ervin, Jr. to participate in oral argument,
as amicus curiae, is granted and a total of 30 minutes is allotted for that
purpose. The Solicitor General is allotted 30 additional minutes for
oral argument.
No. 71-1031. Leonard Tonasket, appellant, v. Washington et al.
The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief expressing the views of
the United States.

tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Michigan denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 71–993. Margaret Lovisi, petitioner, v. Virginia. Motion of
respondent to dispense with printing brief granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Virginia denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that cretiorari should be granted.
No. 71-5560. William Isaac Miller, petitioner, v. Oregon. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Oregon denied.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 71–5726. Robert L. Hunt, petitioner, v. Georgia et al. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall are
of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-5989. Harry William Theriault et al., petitioners, v. Fred-
erick Silber et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied. Mr.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 71-5990. Jean Sinclair, petitioner, v. John W. Turner,
Warden. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice White took no part
in the consideration or decision of this petition.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 71-5564. James Stewart et al., petitioners, v. William S.
White et al. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of mandamus
and/or prohibition and for other relief denied.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr.
Justice Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit during the week of
May 22, 1972, and for such additional time in advance thereof to pre-
pare for the hearing of cases, and for such further time as may be
required to complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294
(a), is ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28
U.S.C. § 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until Monday, April 10,
1972.

No. 70-5026. Claude Alexander, petitioner, v. Louisiana. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Louisiana for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr.
Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this case.
No. 70-5014. Peter Stanley, Sr., petitioner, v. Illinois. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Illinois for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White. Mr. Justice Douglas joins in Parts I and II of the
opinion. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger with whom
Mr. Justice Blackmun joins. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-5082. Laverne Carter et al., appellants, v. Wayne Stanton
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of Indiana. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Southern District of Indiana for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Separate
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, April 10, 1972, at 10 o'clock.

TUESDAY, APRIL 11, 1972
486
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
ADMISSIONS TO THE BAR ON ORAL MOTION
Movant
Applicant
Daniel A. Utter
C. Emmett Pugh
City and State
Minneapolis, Minn.
New Orleans, La.
Robert Emery Coyle.
Harold J. Birch.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today we take note with sadness of the death of former Justice
James F. Byrnes in his 93rd year. Justice Byrnes served on this Court
in 1941 and 1942 at which time he resigned from the Court upon being
appointed by President Roosevelt as Director of the Office of Economic
Stabilization. Our sadness on the death of Mr. Justice Byrnes is
tempered by the knowledge of the full and rich and remarkable life
he lived, serving as he did in the House of Representatives, in the
United States Senate, as Governor of the State of South Carolina, as
Secretary of State, and as a Justice of this Court. He therefore served
with great distinction at the highest levels in all three branches of
Government, as well as in the highest office of his native state. His
contributions to stability and peace following World War II have
made his name honored among the statesmen of his time.
"Few men have served their country so long or so well.
"The record will show that adjournment of this Court today will be
in memory of Mr. Justice Byrnes."
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Justice Marshall will not be present today but will participate
in the cases to be argued on the basis of the entire record, briefs, and
the tape recording of the oral arguments."

Brittin, Jr., for the petitioners and by Mr. Larry S. Seuferer for the
respondents.

MONDAY, APRIL 17, 1972

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-44. Jerry Dennis Rothstein, appellant, v. Lutheran Social
Services of Wisconsin and Upper Michigan. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Wisconsin. Motion to strike appellant's supplemental
brief denied. Judgment vacated and case remanded to Supreme Court
of Wisconsin for further consideration in light of Stanley v. Illinois,
405 U.S. (1972) with due consideration for the completion of the
adoption proceedings and the fact that the child has apparently lived
with the adoptive family for the intervening period of time.
-
-
No. 71-9. Lawrence Lung et al., appellants, v. Franklin Jones et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of New
Mexico. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the District of New Mexico for further considera-
tion in light of Lynch v. Household Finance Corp., 405 U.S. — (1972).
No. 71–793. David Arthur Anderson et al., appellants, v. Mary-
land. Appeal from the Court of Special Appeals of Maryland. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be
noted.
No. 71-940. Robert D. Brusca et al., appellants, v. State Board of
Education et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Missouri. Judgment affirmed.
No. 71-5974. Donald Harold Morris, appellant, v. Georgia. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 71-6067. James E. Diggs. Jr., appellant, v. Benjamin Franklin
University. Appeal from the District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
480-278-72--100

MONDAY, APRIL 17, 1972
489
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 71-6082. Luke Joseph Rener, appellant, v. George J. Beto.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Motion of The American Civil Liberties Union for leave to file a brief,
as amicus curiae, granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-123. Roger Vanderlaan, petitioner, v. Antonia Vanderlaan.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois,
First District. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First Dis-
trict, for further consideration in light of Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S.
— (1972).
No. 70-142. Donald L. Garren and James A. Eddinger, petitioners,
v. City of Winston-Salem, North Carolina. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in
light of Lynch v. Household Finance Corp.. 405 U.S. — (1972).
No. 70-249. Stanley V. Tucker, petitioner, v. Joseph D. Maher
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of Lynch v. Household Finance
Corp., 405 U.S. — (1972).
No. 71-5580. Rudy Gonzales, petitioner, v. George J. Beto, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Corrections. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals. Turner v. Louisiana, 379 U.S. 466. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in the judgment with whom Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice White joins.

appellant, v. El Paso Natural Gas Company et al. The motion for
modification of the mandate (judgment) and for other relief is denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

Conservation Center, petitioner, v. Robert Clyde Bustamonte. The

ordered that Stuart P. Tobisman, Esquire, of Los Angeles, California,
be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent,
pro hac vice, in this case.
No. 71–829. Leila Mourning, petitioner, v. Family Publications
Service, Inc. The motion of the petitioner for leave to proceed further
herein in forma pauperis is granted.
No. 71-1016. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Louisiana
Power & Light Company et al.; and
No. 71-1040. United Gas Pipe Line Company et al., petitioners, v.
Louisiana Power & Light Company et al. The motions of the Atlanta
Gas Light Company et al.; and the Monsanto Company et al., for
leave to file briefs, as amici curiae, are granted. The motion of the
Humble Oil & Refining Company for leave to fire a brief, as amicus
curiae, is granted. The motions of the State of Louisiana; and the
Humble Oil & Refining Company for leave to participate in oral
argument, as amicus curiae, are denied. The motion of the Mobile
Gas Service Corporation et al., for leave to participate in oral argu-
ment, as amici curiae, is denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of these motions.

decision of these cases.

jurisdiction postponed to hearing of case on the merits.

ORDER
It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for special assign-
ments, be suspended for the term upon the conclusion of the argu-
ments in the cases listed for hearing this week.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 24, 1972, until
Monday, May 15, 1972.

No. 71–257. T. R. Grubbs dba T. R. Grubbs Tire & Appliance,
petitioner, v. General Electric Credit Corporation. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further consideration of respondent's appeal on the merits. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 70-14. Jonathan O. Cole, Superintendent, Boston State Hos-
pital, et al., appellants, v. Lucretia Peteros Richardson. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the District of Massachusetts for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr.
Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.

513
No. 70-223. Central Hardware Company, petitioner, v. National
Labor Relations Board et al. One hour and twenty minutes allowed for
oral argument. Argued by Mr. Ronald L. Aylward for the petitioner,
by Mr. Norton J. Come for respondent National Labor Relations

The Chief Justice said:
"The Court is in Special Session this afternoon to receive the Resolu-
tions of the Bar in tribute to Mr. Justice Black. Before we commence
the proceedings, I am requested to remind you that all present are in-
vited by Mrs. Black and the Black family to attend the reception in the
East Conference Room at the close of this proceeding.
Mr. Solicitor General Griswold addressed the Court as follows:
"Mr. Chief Justice, May it Please the Court:
"At the meeting of the members of the Bar of the Supreme Court
just concluded, resolutions expressing profound sorrow at the death
of Justice Hugo Lafayette Black were offered by a committee of which
Mr. Louis Oberdorfer was Chairman.
"Addresses and resolutions were presented by Bernard G. Segal
of the Philadelphia Bar, by Professor Paul A. Freund of Cambridge,
Massachusetts, and by Mr. George Saunders of the Illinois Bar.
"The resolutions unanimously adopted are as follows:
"RESOLUTIONS
"We meet to honor the memory of Justice Hugo LaFayette Black..
"To each Member of your Committee that memory is a vivid one-
for Justice Black was a vivid man. Some of us knew him in his public
life before he came to the Court; some of us knew him across the Bar
in our appearances before this Court; some of us knew him by virtue
of our service as his law clerks; some of us knew him as the attentive,
inspiring Circuit Justice for the Fifth Circuit.
"Vignettes from our memories abound.
"Senator Sparkman, Congressman Pepper and others of us first.
remember Justice Black as Senator Black-feared and fearless in-
vestigator, architect of New Deal legislation, Administration leader
on the Senate Floor, Chairman of the Labor and Education Commit-

TUESDAY, APRIL 18, 1972
514
tee and an influential Member of the Finance, Foreign Affairs, Military
Affairs and Rules Committees.
"Their recollections from the 1930's picture Senator Black's desk
piled high with volumes of American, English and Ancient history
and classics. He was then still heavily engaged in the compensatory
liberal education which he had begun in 1926, while enjoying and
making the most of the relative anonymity of a freshman Senator.
"The advocates among us will most vividly remember Justice Black,
senior Justice for over 25 of his 34 years on the Court, as he appeared
on the bench-"dwarfed" alongside the several relatively substantial
gentlemen who were successively his Chief Justices. When he could be
seen from the Bar, he usually appeared tanned from tennis (even in
the winter), gently rocking, alternately thumbing through briefs, or
with his head slightly cocked, alertly watching counsel-often, it
seemed, awaiting an appropriate moment to pounce a question in his
inimitable Alabama manner.
"One humbler counsellor recalls from an argument concerning the
power of a Judicial Conference to control the work of a Federal Dis-
trict Judge, "the tone of disbelief" with which Justice Black put
a question:
"'Mr. JUSTICE BLACK. You mean that the President of the
United States, in your judgment, has the power under our con-
stitution to determine whether a judge is mentally able to try his
cases? Is that what you are saying?
""Mr. WRIGHT. I am saying exactly that; yes, sir.
"'Mr. JUSTICE BLACK. I think I understand you now.'
"According to the counsellor, Justice Black "leaned far back in his
chair, shaking his head but with a twinkle in his eye.'
"1
"In a last colloquy with counsel Justice Black evoked from the
Solicitor General a concession which the Justice, with obvious relish,
built into his last opinion:
"You [Mr. Justice Black] say that no law means no law, and
that should be obvious. I [the Solicitor General] can only say
Mr. Justice that to me it is equally obvious that 'no law' does not
mean 'no law', and I would seek to persuade the Court that that
is true. ** *12
"Those of us who were law clerks to Justice Black have shared a
special precious privilege. We have, in our small ways, assisted and
closely observed the steely-disciplined working habits of a self-taught
scholar as he resurrected from his own reading and experience and
propagated with his own carefully penned eloquence a fresh, authentic
and now widely-though not universally-accepted appreciation of
1 Wright, Hugo L. Black: a Great Man and a Great American, 50 Tex. L. Rev. 1, 2-3
(1971).
2 New York Times Co. v. United States, 403 U.S. 713, 717–18, (1971).

TUESDAY, APRIL 18, 1972
515
the genius of our nation's written Constitution. In the process we have
pitted, or attempted to pit, ourselves in intellectual combat against
what Justice Cardozo once described as one of the most brilliant legal
minds he had ever known.³
"Our privilege included a brief but intimate membership in a family
presided over by a very great man, deeply in love with his wife and
not ashamed to show it. We have observed first hand how even the
greatest of men can be inspired to greater heights of effort and insight
by the unflagging support and admiration of a loved and loving wife.
"The bonds between Justice Black and his law clerks did not end with
the termination of each law clerk's service. They were renewed by
frequent visits, correspondence and formal gatherings for important
anniversaries and birthdays. On his 80th birthday, Justice Black spoke
to his clerks and their wives about the disadvantages and advantages
of growing old. The disadvantages were obvious enough and he related
some. There were also surprising advantages: 'As one grows old, one
needs less sleep.' That, said Justice Black, 'gives that much more time
to work.'
4
"One of Justice Black's law clerks recently wrote an extremely
popular, but controversial, book. It was Justice Black's habit to focus
on his reading by heavy underscoring and frequent longhand penciled
margin notes. Justice Black's copy of this law clerk's book carries in
its margin some trenchant annotations.
"The author wrote of the glory of the original American dream of
a free democratic society, observing sadly that:
""Less than two hundred years later almost every aspect of the
dream has been lost. In this chapter we shall be concerned with
the forces that destroyed the American dream.5
In the margin Justice Black wrote in heavy pencil :
"I do not agree. It is not yet destroyed."
The law clerk-author, striving to identify a new set of values for
our society, bluntly disparaged the old. He wrote:
"[Our earliest generation known as] Consciousness I believe
that the American dream is still possible, and that success is deter-
mined by character, morality, hard work, and self-denial. ***6
"In the margin Justice Black's longhand note proclaimed:
"'I still do.'
"The judges of the Fifth Circuit have been favored for many
years by the inspiring presence of Justice Black at their annual Judi-
cial Conferences. The last 18 years have been trying ones for Fifth
3 Hazel Black Davis, Uncle Hugo: An Intimate Portrait of Mr. Justice Black 54 (1965)
(privately printed).
4 C. Reich, The Greening of America (1970).
5 Id. at 20.
6 Id. at 24.

TUESDAY, APRIL 18, 1972
516
Circuit Judges. Justice Black shared those trials while he provided
leadership and reassurance that "this, too, will pass." The Fifth Cir-
cuit Judges perhaps appreciate, more than others, the full implica-
tions of Justice Black's role in this Court's steadfast effort to eliminate
unconstitutional discrimination in our land. He was the only Justice
from the Deep South when the Court decided Brown. As on other
occasions when he was personally attacked, he silently suffered with
manly dignity the unpleasant reprisals inflicted upon him and his
loved ones in the South. Nor did he flinch in his determination to see
it through. As a single Circuit Justice he finalized the order for the
admission of James Meredith to the University of Mississippi, the
enforcement of which required a substantial military operation. As
Circuit Justice, and with the full Court, he eliminated the 'all deliberate
speed' concept as a brake on school desegregation."
"In an informal farewell address to one of the last Judicial Con.
ferences of his Circuit which he attended Justice Black spoke of his
pride in the way the Southern federal judges had performed their
difficult and often unpopular duty of applying the Constitution and en-
forcing the civil rights laws, particularly with respect to the Brown
decision. He reminded them of the constancy of controversy and his
belief that he and they were strengthened by it. In conclusion he told
them good-by. He said:
"I have been coming to see you for thirty years, how many more
I cannot know. I, too, like many of the judges I have seen here,
have passed over the crest, over the brow of the hill. I hope I have
learned more tolerance, more friendship, more about the love of
human kindness during those thirty years.
""Now I am far beyond the crest. I look over into the glowing
rays that come with sunset. The years have been happy for me;
the people have been good to me. I have no complaint about my
life, and as I look at those rays they do not frighten me. I know
that life is change, and the greatest change of all is who is to be
here at any certain period. All that I can say and hope for is that
my career has been such that people of integrity of thought,
when they think about me, will picture a person who tried his
dead level best to serve his people and his country with every
ounce of energy, love and devotion that he could muster in his
life, and that, when those rays cease to be in my vision, each of you
and every member of this Conference will remember me as one
who did his best.'
"For most of his years on the Bench Justice Black adhered to a
strictly ascetic view of a judge's role and made no serious public state-
ments. In his later years he relented to the extent of delivering the
First James Madison Lecture on the First Amendment, explaining his
philosophy of the Constitution in an hour-long television special en-
7 Alexander v. Holmes County Bd. of Ed., 396 U.S. 1218 (1969) (Black, Circuit Justice)
(opinion in Chambers).
480-278-72-104

TUESDAY, APRIL 18, 1972
517
titled 'Mr. Justice Black and the Bill of Rights,' and delivering the
Carpentier Lectures at Columbia University. In the latter he under-
took to state 'in simple and clear language' his 'constitutional faith.'
He opened the Lectures with the observation that:
"[I]t is of paramount importance that our country has a writ-
ten Constitution the purpose of which was to 'establish govern-
ments controlled by the people themselves.' Carpentier Lectures,
p. 5.
"Justice Black continued with simple eloquence to express his faith
in the Constitution as an ingenious instrument to be invoked by the
Supreme Court to assure control of government by the people subject
to restraints specifically embodied in the Constitution primarily to
limit government power and to protect minorities from majorities.
"Justice Black's deep faith in the Constitution expressed near the
end of his long service on this Court was built upon rich experience as
an active, successful trial lawyer, a fair and efficient municipal court
judge, a vigorous prosecutor, candidate for public office, and as United
States Senator.8 His time on the Court began as the country struggled
to design solutions for the social and economic problems generated and
widened by the great depression. It continued through World War II,
the Cold War confrontations with their corollary domestic shock
waves, the conflicts which followed in the wake of the Brown deci-
sion and finally, in the 1960's, the violence of assassinations, street
crime, increased racial tension and an unpopular war.
"In his later years, he sparred with commentators and colleagues
who claimed that his fundamental views had changed with these
changing times. He disagreed:
"I think that I can say categorically that I have not changed
my basic constitutional philosophy-at least not in the last 40
years.'⁹
"He convinced at least one commentator who recently concluded:
""The remarkable thing about him was not his ability to change
with the times but the timelessness of the values of justice, free-
dom and human dignity, to which he held, and for which he
fought.' 10
"Justice Black came to the Court committed, as a Senator, to the
view that popular control of the government was frustrated by what
he deemed to be excessive judicial restraints drawn from the Due Proc-
ess clause and the Commerce Clause of the Constitution.11 From the
beginning to the end of his service he fought what he considered to be
unauthorized efforts of judges to supersede the judgment of voters and
8 For a posthumous account of Justice Black's pre-Court years, see Hamilton, Hugo
Black, The Alabama Years (1972).
Carpentier Lectures, p. 3 (March 20, 1968).
10 Durr, Hugo Black, A Personal Appraisal, Ga. L. Rev. (to be published).
11 See, e.g., Cong. Rec., 72d Cong., 2d Sess., 1443-44 (1935).

TUESDAY, APRIL 18, 1972
518
their elected representatives with the judges' views of appropriate
remedies for social and economic problems.12
"Justice Black also came to the Court convinced that it had an affirm-
ative responsibility to make other branches of the national govern-
ment as fully responsive to the will of the people as was consistent with
orderly process and protection of minorities. His experience and read-
ing reinforced his faith in the practical wisdom of the separation of
powers effected by the Constitution between the Executive, Legislative
and Judicial branches of government and between the national gov-
ernment and the states. He repeatedly urged the Court to review and
strike down attempts by the Executive to legislate, adjudicate or en-
gage in activity proscribed, or not plainly authorized; 13 by the Legis-
lature to adjudicate or enforce through Congressional Committees or
by personal legislation resembling bills of attainder; 14 and by the
Judiciary to legislate or administer. 15 Any significant weakening of the
careful separation contemplated by the Constitution could, he believed,
lead to an inordinate accretion of power in one or another of the
branches which would tempt the overreaching branch to destroy or
undermine the others and then turn, unfettered, upon the people, frus-
trating their will and tyrannically abusing their liberties.
"As Justice Black was helping to confine the power of judges
to restrain the people's elected representatives from addressing them-
selves to solutions of pressing social and economic needs, he also sought
to direct the Court's prestige and power toward what he conceived as
primary roles which were fashioned for it by the plain words of the
Constitution. Drawing on his experience as a prosecutor, a judge and a
12 See, e.g., Hugo L. Black, "Reorganization of the Federal Judiciary," a radio address
reported in New York Times, arch 30, 1937.
13 "In the framework of our Constitution, the President's power to see that the laws are
faithfully executed refutes the idea that he is to be a lawmaker. The Constitution limits
his functions in the law-making process to the recommending of laws he thinks wise and the
vetoing of laws he thinks bad. And the Constitution is neither silent nor equivocal about
who shall make laws which the President is to execute. The first section of the first article
says that 'All legislative Powers herein granted shall be vested in a Congress of the United
States. ***"
"The Founders of this Nation entrusted the law-making power to the Congress alone in
good and bad times. It would do no good to recall the historical events, the fears of power
and the hopes of freedom that lay behind their choice. Such a review would but confirm
our holding that this seizure order cannot stand." Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Sawyer,
343 U.S. 579, 587-89 (1952). See also, Gregory v. Chicago, 394 U.S. 113, 120 (1968)
(Black J., concurring).
14 "Those who wrote our Constitution well knew the danger inherent in special legisla-
tive acts which take away the life, liberty, or property of particular named persons because
the legislature thinks them guilty of conduct which deserves punishment. They intended to
safeguard the people of this country from punishment without trial by duly constituted
courts. * * * When our Constitution and Bill of Rights were written, our ancestors had
ample reason to know that legislative trials and punishments were too dangerous to
liberty to exist in the nation of free men they envisioned. And so they proscribed bills of
attainder." United States v. Lovett, 328 U.S. 303, 317-18 (1946).
15 Justice Black's insistence that the judiciary stay within the province of deciding
specific cases presented to it by litigants is probably best demonstrated by his repeated
dissents from the Court's promulgation of rules, such as the Federal Rules of Civil Pro-
cedure. See, e.g., Statement of Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Douglas, 374 U.S. 865-66
(1963):
"We believe that while some of the Rules of Civil Procedure are simply housekeeping
details, many determine matters so substantially affecting the rights of litigants in law-
suits that in practical effect they are the equivalent of new legislation which, in our
judgment, the Constitution requires to be initiated in and enacted by the Congress and
approved by the President. The Constitution, as we read it, provides that all laws shall
be enacted by the House, the Senate and the President, not by the mere failure of Congress
to reject proposals of an outside agency."

TUESDAY, APRIL 18, 1972
519
Senator, he used simple but eloquent language to focus and renew the
attention of his Brethren and the public upon three particular elements
of orderly government by the people under our Constitution: full
adherence to the procedural protections to the Bill of Rights and
other provisions of the Constitution designed to protect the individual
from abuse of government power; free and universal access to the
political process; and absolute freedom of speech, belief and thought.
I
"In his grand jury investigation of police brutality and other first
hand experience while serving as Solicitor of Jefferson County, Ala-
bama, Hugo Black had witnessed the helplessness of the poor and the
unfortunate when confronted by the power of government and the
corrupting effect of official lawlessness. A 1915 Grand Jury investigat-
ing police brutality in Bessemer, Alabama, had filed a report (very
likely written for it by the special prosecutor who conducted the
investigation, Hugo Black) which concluded:
"A man does not forfeit his right to be treated as a human
being by reason of the fact that he is charged with, or an officer
suspects that he is guilty of a crime. Instead of being ready and
waiting to strike a prisoner in his custody, an officer should protect
him. Such practices are dishonorable, tyrannical, and despot-
ic, and such rights must not be surrendered to any officer or set of
officers, so long as human life is held sacred, and human liberty
and human safety of paramount importanc.16
In his third term on the Supreme Court Justice Black was confronted
by a case in which his Alabama experience and his Constitutional
philosophy merged to produce an early, and possibly immortal, expres-
sion of the role of the courts in providing fair trials for the helpless
citizen threatened by government. In Chambers v. Florida, 309 U.S.
227, 240–41 (1940), four young Negro tenant farmers petitioned the
Court to reverse their murder convictions based on confessions obtained
after seven days of uninterrupted grilling. Justice Black's majority
opinion in that case struck a note which he resounded again and again
over the years:
"We are not impressed by the argument that law enforce-
ment methods such as those under review are necessary to uphold
our laws. The Constitution proscribes such lawless means irrespec-
tive of the end. And this argument flouts the basic principle that
all people must stand on an equality before the bar of justice
in every American court. Today, as in ages past, we are not with-
out tragic proof that the exalted power of some governments to
punish manufactured crime dictatorially is the handmaid of
tyranny. Under our Constitutional system, courts stand against
any winds that blow as havens or refuge for those who might
16 See Birmingham, Age-Herald, September 18, 1915.

TUESDAY, APRIL 18, 1972
520
otherwise suffer because they are helpless, weak, outnumbered,
or because they are non-conforming victims of prejudice and pub-
lic excitement. Due process of law, preserved for all by our Con-
stitution, commands that no such practice as that disclosed by this
record shall send any accused to his death. No higher duty, no
more solemn responsibility, rests upon this Court, than that of
translating into living law and maintaining this constitutional
shield deliberately planned and inscribed for the benefit of every
human being subject to our Constitution of whatever race, creed,
or persuasion."
"Justice Black also knew from his own experience as prosecutor and
defense counsel that a defendant could seldom, if ever, receive a just
trial without representation by an attorney. How could a defendant,
even one released on bail, marshall the facts? How could he compre-
hend the legal questions? How could be avoid the procedural pitfalls
and traps built into the criminal justice system? How could he ap-
proach the bench and address the learned judge? How could he choose
the jury?
"In a 1942 case, involving a poor unemployed farm hand who was
tried without the aid of counsel and convicted, Justice Black stated
his strongly held view, which he believed he shared with the men who
wrote the Sixth Amendment, that a lawyer is indispensable to a de-
fendant on trial for his liberty. Betts v. Brady. 316 U.S. 455, 476–77
(1942). While Justice Black's dissent argued that the Fourteenth
Amendment made the Sixth Amendment applicable to the States, he
also maintained that:
"A practice cannot be reconciled with "common and funda-
mental ideas of fairness and right," which subjects innocent men
to increased dangers of conviction merely because of their poverty.
Whether a man is innocent cannot be determined from a trial in
which, as here, denial of counsel has made it impossible to con-
clude, with any satisfactory degree of certainty, that the defend-
ant's case was adequately presented.***
'[N]o man **** [should] be deprived of counsel merely be-
cause of his poverty. Any other practice seems to be to defeat
the promise of our democratic society to provide equal justice
