Paul F. Peters.
Amendments to the Federal Rules for Criminal Procedure and Fed-
eral Rules of Appellate Procedure, adopted pursuant to Title 18,
United States Code, Sections 3771 and 3772. Mr. Justice Douglas
dissents to adoption of proposed Rule 50 (b) of the Federal Rules of
Criminal Procedure.
OPINIONS
No. 70-5112. Willie Mae Weber, petitioner, v. Aetna Casualty &
Surety Company et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Louisiana. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme
Court of Louisiana for further proceedings not inconsistent with the

MONDAY, APRIL 24, 1972
564
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
No. 70-78. Affiliated Ute Citizens of the State of Utah et al., peti-
tioners, v. United States et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment in AUC case af-
firmed. Judgment in the Reyos case affirmed in part and reversed in
part. Case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas concurring in part and dis-
senting in part. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 17, Original. State of Nebraska, plaintiff, v. State of Iowa. On
exceptions to the Report of the Special Master. Exceptions to
the Report of the Special Master overruled. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan.
No. 70-88. S&E Contractors, Inc., petitioner, v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the United States Court of Claims for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart
and Mr. Justice Powell join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Bren-
nan with whom Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr.
Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 49, Original. State of Illinois, Plaintiff, v. City of Milwaukee,
Wisconsin, et al. On motion for leave to file bill of complaint. Motion
denied without prejudice. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 45, Original. State of Washington et al., plaintiffs, v. General
Motors Corporation et al. On motion for leave to file bill of complaint.
The motions of the States of North Dakota and West Virginia to be
joined as parties plaintiff are granted. Motion for leave to file bill of
complaint denied without prejudice. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these
motions.
No. 50. Original. State of Vermont, plaintiff, v. State of New York
et al. On motion for leave to file bill of complaint. Motion granted.
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger
Adjourned until Monday, May 15, 1972, at 10 o'clock.

SATURDAY, APRIL 29, 1972
565
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
PER CURIAM OPINION
No. 71-1024. Sixty-Seventh Minnesota State Senate, appellant, v.
Richard A. Bcens et al.; and
No. 71-1145. Sixty-Seventh Minnesota State Senate, appellant, v.
Richard A. Beens et al. Appeals from the United States District Court
for the District of Minnesota. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the United States District Court for the District of Minnesota for
further proceedings consistent with the opinion of this Court. The
judgement shall issue forthwith. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart.

FRIDAY, MAY 5, 1972
566
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall,
Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1106. Georgia et al., applicants, v. United States. The appli-
cation of the United States to vacate the stay order of this Court here-
tofore granted on April 21, 1972, is denied. Mr. Chief Justice Burger,
Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Stewart are of the opinion that
the application should be granted.
No. A-1116. Martin W. Essex, Superintendent of Public Schools
of the State of Ohio, et al., applicants, v. Benson A. Wolman et al. The
application for a stay of the order of the United States District Court
for the Southern District of Ohio, Civ No. 71-396, presented to Mr.
Justice Stewart and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Chief
Justice Burger, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist are of
the opinion that the application should be granted.
No. A-1121. Milton Luros et al., applicants, v. United States Dis-
trict Court for the Southern District of California et al. The applica-
tion for a stay presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to
the Court, is denied.

480-278-72—————114

FRIDAY, MAY 12, 1972
567
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall,
Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-1179. Richard G. Kleindienst, Acting Attorney General.
et al., applicant, v. The Washington Post Co., et al. The application of
the Solicitor General for a stay of the judgment of the United States
District Court for the District of Columbia (Civil Action No. 467–72),
presented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court, is
granted pending appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit. Mr. Justice Douglas would deny the
stay and leave Judge Gesell's order in effect pending appeal. See
Heuvel, The Press and the Prisons, Columbia Journalism Rev. p. 35
(May/June 1972). Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall
are of the opinion that the application should be denied.

MONDAY, MAY 15, 1972
568
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-801. County of Alameda et al., appellants, v. California
Welfare Rights Organization et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of California. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 71-6256. Francisco Cepero Alers, appellant, v. Superior Court
of Puerto Rico, etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71–6360. Tibor Ivan Toczauer, appellant, v. State Board of
Registration for Professional Engineers of the State of California.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 71-1094. Stephen Charles Crowder, bnf Charles Edward
Crowder, appellant, v. Georgia et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 71-1156. John A. Grivetti, Jr., et al., appellants, v. Illinois
State Electoral Board et al.; and
No. 71-1246. Independent Voters of Illinois et al., appellants, v.
John W. Lewis et al. Appeals from the United States District Court
for the Northern District of Illinois. Judgment affirmed.
No. 71-1176. Russell G. Oswald, Commissioner of Correctional
Services of the State of New York, et al., appellants, v. Esther Frances
Gesicki et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of New York. Judgment affirmed.
No. 71-5872. Phillip Van Eeghen, appellant, v. Florida et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the Middle District
of Florida. Judgment affirmed.
480-278-72—116

MONDAY, MAY 15, 1972
569
No. 71–6372. Kevin D. Cleary, appellant, v. District of Columbia.
Appeal from the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon.
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would postpone consideration of the
question of jurisdiction to the hearing of the case on the merits.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-5515. Ella Metcalf et al., petitioners, v. Harold O. Swank
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration
in light of Carter v. Stanton, — U.S. — (1972). Mr. Justice Rehnquist
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1105. Ben W. Fortson, Jr., appellant, v. G. Everett Millican.
The motion of the appellee to vacate the stay order of this Court
dated April 21, 1972, is denied.
No. A-1165. In matter of the disbarment of William M. Morton,
Jr. It is ordered that William M. Morton, Jr., of St. Joseph, Missouri,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
to show cause issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to
show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law
in this Court.
No. 27, Original. State of Ohio, plaintiff, v. State of Kentucky. The
Report of the Special Master upon the motion of the State of Ohio is
received and ordered filed. Exceptions, if any, with supporting briefs
may be filed within sixty days. Reply briefs, if any, may be filed within
thirty days of the receipt of the exceptions.
No. 71-718. Paul D. McGinnis, Commissioner of Correction, State
of New York, et al., appellants, v. James Royster et al. The motion
of the appellees for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
No. 71-1016. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Louisiana
Power & Light Company, et al.; and
No. 71-1040. United Gas Pipe Line Company et al., petitioners, v.
Louisiana Power & Light Company et al. The motion of the Mobile
Gas Corporation et al., for leave to file a supplemental amici curiae
brief, after argument, is granted. Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice.
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 71–5908. Leon Chambers, petitioner, v. Mississippi. The mo-
tion of Ramsey Clark to permit Peter Westen to argue orally, pro hac
vice, on behalf of the petitioner, is granted.

OPINIONS
No. 71–300. Thomas L. Andrews, petitioner, v. Louisville & Nash-
ville Railroad Company et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 71-123. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Burns
International Security Services, Inc., et al.; and
No. 71-198. Burns International Security Services, Inc., petitioner,
v. National Labor Relations Board et al. On writs of certiorari to the

AND CINES REMANDED TO COURT OF APPEALS FOR FURTHER
PROCEEDINGS IN CONFORMITY WITH THE OPINION OF THIS
COURT
MONDAY, MAY 15, 1972
601
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment
affirmed Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist concurring in No. 71-123 and dissenting in No. 71-198
with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr
Justice Powell join.
No. 71–81. United States, petitioner, v. Loarn Anthony Biswell. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 71-5172. Charles O. Dukes, petitioner, v. Warden, Connecti-
cut State Prison. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Con-
necticut. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins.
No. 70-110. Wisconsin, petitioner, v. Jonas Yoder et al. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Brennan jonis. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Stewart join. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas dissenting
in part. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 71-107. Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company, petitioner,
v. Erie Lackawanna Railroad Company et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
No. 71-5097. Harold Eugene Huffman, petitioner, v. Faye I.
Boersen. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Neb-
raska for further consideration not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Adjourned until Monday, May 22, 1972, at 10 o'clock.
☑

MONDAY, MAY 22, 1972
602
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Jus-
tice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-1068. Midwest Freight Forwarding Company, Inc., et al.,
appellants v. John W. Lewis, Secretary of State of Illinois, et al. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 71-1142. United States, appellant, v. John M. Harper. The
motion to dispense with printing the motion to affirm is granted.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Massachusetts. Judgment vacated and the case remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of Massachusetts with direc-
tions to dismiss the proceedings as moot.
No. 71-1264. Donald Ferrell et al., appellants, v. David Hall, Gov-
ernor of Oklahoma, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Western District of Oklahoma. Judgment affirmed. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should
be noted.
No. 71-5998. Frank R. Hayes, appellant, v. California. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-589. Ranch-Way, Inc., petitioner, v. National Labor Rela-
tions Board. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of NLRB v. Burns International
Security Services, Inc., et al., 406 U.S.—(1972).
480-278-72-121

MONDAY, MAY 22, 1972
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
603
No. 31, Original. State of Utah, plaintiff, v. United States. Decree
entered.
It is ordered that Honorable Charles Fahy, Senior Judge of the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
be, and he is hereby, appointed Special Master in this case in the place
of Honorable J. Cullen Ganey, deceased. The Special Master shall
have authority to fix the time and conditions for the filing of addi-
tional pleadings and to direct subsequent proceedings, and with au-
thority to summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and take such evidence
as may be introduced and such as he may deem it necessary to call for.
The Master is directed to submit such reports as he may deem appro-
priate.
The Master shall be allowed his actual expenses. The allowances to
him, the compensation paid to his technical, stenographic, and clerical
assistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses
shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such proportion
as the Court hereafter may direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in this
case becomes vacant during a recess of Court The Chief Justice shall
have authority to make new designation which shall have the same
effect as if originally made by the Court herein.
No. 36, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of Louisiana.
The Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed. Excep-
tions, if any, may be filed by the parties within 45 days. Reply briefs,
if any, may be filed within 30 days.
No. 55, Original. Richard Eugene Webb, a Citizen of Ohio, plain-
tiff, v. William J. Porter, as Ambassador and Chief of the United
States Delegation to the Paris Peace Talks. The motion for leave to
file a bill of complaint is denied.
No. 71–237. Vincent R. Mancusi, Warden, petitioner, v. William
C. Stubbs. The motions of the respondent for the appointment of
counsel and for leave to proceed in forma pauperis are granted.
No. 71–257. T. R. Grubbs dba T. R. Grubbs Tire & Appliance, pe-
titioner, v. General Electric Credit Corporation. The motion of the
petitioner for a determination of the cause on the merits is denied.
No. 71-507. Wilfred Keyes et al., petitioners, v. School District
No. 1, Denver, Colorado, et al. The motion of the Anti-Defamation
League of B'nai B'rith et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae,
is granted. The motion of the National Education Association et al.,
for leave to file a brief, as
curiae, is granted. The motion of
the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund for leave
AMIC

MONDAY, MAY 22, 1972
604
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. Mr. Justice White took no
part in the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 71-685. Robert J. Lehnausen, petitioner, v. Lake Shore Auto
Parts Co. et al.; and
No. 71-691. Edward J. Barrett, County Clerk of Cook County,
Illinois, et al., petitioners, v. Clemens K. Shapiro et al. The motion
of Lake Shore Auto Parts Co. for leave to withdraw as a party re-
spondent in No. 71-685 is denied. The motion for an order requiring
petitioners to recognize "Maynard Respondents" as parties to the liti-
gation is denied without prejudice to seeking leave to appear as amicus
curiae.
No. 71-703. United States, appellant, v. First National Bancor-
poration, Inc., et al. The motion of the New York State Banking De-
partment for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae, is granted. Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 71-732. Merle R. Schneckloth, Superintendent, California
Conservation Center, petitioner, v. Robert Clyde Bustamonte. The
motion of the respondent for additional time for oral argument is
denied. However, permission is granted for two counsel to argue on
behalf of the respondent.
No. 71-900. Union Oil Company of California, petitioner, v. The
Tugboat San Jacinto et al. The motion to dispense with printing the
appendix and to proceed on the original record is denied.
No. 71-1263. Edmund D. Kahn et ux., appellants, v. Arizona State
Tax Commission. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 71-1443. California Department of Human Resources Devel-
opment et al., petitioners, a. Ellenmae Crow, etc. The motion of the
petitioners to expedite consideration and for consolidation with No.
71-1119 is denied.
No. 71–1476. J. Brian Gaffney, appellant, v. Theodore R. Cum-
mings et al. The motion of the appellant to expedite consideration is
denied. The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist join in denying the expedited consideration on the merits but
would invite the appellant to file an appropriate motion for a stay.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 71-991. Otter Tail Power Company, appellant. v. United
States. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Minnesota. In this case probable jurisdiction noted. Mr. Justice
Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this matter.

No. 71-1470. Alton J. Lemon et al., appellants, v. David H. Kurtz-
man, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Application for an extension of
the injunction, presented to Mr. Justice Brennan and by him referred
to the Court, granted. In this case probable jurisdiction noted. Mo-
tion to expedite denied.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit during the period
beginning June 5, 1972, and ending June 9, 1972, and for such further
time as may be required to complete unfinished business, pursuant to
28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered on the minutes of this Court,
pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until Tuesday, May 30, 1972.

Robert Stanley Zack
No. 70-117. Charles Joseph Kastigar and Michael Gorean Stew-
art, petitioners, v. United States. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice.
Brennan and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 69-4. Joseph Arthur Zicarelli, appellant, v. The New Jersey
State Commission of Investigation. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of New Jersey. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Mr.
Justice Douglas dissents for the reasons stated in his dissenting opin-
ion in No. 70-117, ante. Mr. Justice Marshall dissents for the reasons
stated in his dissenting opinion in No. 70–117, ante. Mr. Justice Bren-

MONDAY, MAY 22, 1972
619
nan and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 70-220. Mortimer M. Caplin, etc., petitioner, v. The Marine
Midland Grace Trust Company of New York. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
White and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.
No. 69-5035. Frank Johnson, appellant, v. Louisiana. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Mr. Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun in
this case and in No. 69–5046, post. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell
concurring in this case and concurring in the judgment in No. 69–
5046 post. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join in this case and in
No. 69-5064 post. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins in this case and in No. 69-5046 post.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins in this case
and in No. 69-5046 post.
No. 69-5046. Robert Apodaca, Henry Morgan Cooper, Jr., and
James Arnold Madden, petitioners, v. Oregon. On writ of certiorari
to the Court of Appeals of Oregon. Judgments affirmed. Mr. Justice
White announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion
in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr.
Justice Rehnquist join. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun
in this case and in No. 69-5035, ante. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell
concurring in No. 69–5035, ante, and concurring in the judgment in
this case. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join in this case and in
No. 69-5035, ante. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins in this case and in No. 69–5035, ante.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting opinon by Mr.
Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins in this case
and in No. 69-5345, ante.
No. 71-83. John A. Strait, petitioner, v. Melvin R. Laird, Secre-
tary of Defense, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice

MONDAY, MAY 22, 1972
620
Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Mr. Chief
Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, and Mr. Justice Powell join
Part 1 of this dissent and on that ground would affirm the judgment
of the Court of Appeals.
No. 70-7. Albert Sarno and Chris Cardi, petitioners, v. Illinois
Crime Investigating Commission. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Illinois. Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently
granted. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Mr. Justice Douglas dissents for the reasons stated in his dissenting
opinon in No. 70-117, ante. Mr. Justice Marshall dissents for the
reasons stated in his dissenting opinion in No. 70-117, ante. Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Tuesday, May 30, 1972, at 10 o'clock.
Х

TUESDAY, MAY 30, 1972
621
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-84. Gerardo Catena, appellant, v. New Jersey State Com-
mission of Investigation. Appeal from the Superior Court of New
Jersey, Appellate Division. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas would note juris-
diction and reverse.
No. 71-318. Angelo Bruno Annaloro, appellant, v. New Jersey
State Commission of Investigation. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question. Mr. Justice Douglas would note jurisdiction and reverse.
No. 71-1107. Thomas D. Gee, appellant, v. California. Appeal
from the Appellate Department of the Superior Court of California,
County of Los Angeles. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
71–1276. Sari Knopp Biklen, appellant, c. Board of Educa-
tion, City School District, Syracuse, New York, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Northern District of New York.
Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would note jurisdiction and
reverse. Board of Education v. Barnette, 319 U.S. 624.
No. 71-1289. Non-Resident Taxpayers Association et al, appel-
lants, v. Philadelphia et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of New Jersey. Judgment affirmed.
No. 71-6341. James E. Diggs, Jr., appellant, v. United States.
Appeal from the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
480-278-72-124

TUESDAY, MAY 30, 1972
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
622
No. 70-303. United States, petitioner, v. Jack Korman and Rob-
ert W. Likas. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further consideration in light of Kastigar v. United States,
407 U.S. (1972).
--
No. 71–377. Albert Elias, Superintendent, Yardville Youth Recep-
tion and Correction Center, petitioner, v. Gerardo Catena. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment va-
cated, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consider-
ation in light of Zicarelli v. New Jersey State Commission of Investi-
gation, 406 U.S.- (1972). Mr. Justice Douglas dissents.
No. 71-775. United States, petitioner, v. Lee Cropper. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further considera-
tion in light of Kastigar v. United States, 406 U.S.— (1972).
No. 71-6274. Donald Bruce McGarva, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in
light of the position presently asserted by the government. The Chief
Justice, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist would deny.
Separate statement by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan joins.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-926. (71-6522-Schwartz v. U.S.) John Doe etc., applicant,
v. United States. The application for stay of execution of sentence
for civil contempt presented to Mr. Justice Marshall, and by him
referred to the Court, is granted.
No. 71-718. Paul D. McGinnis, Commissioner of Correction, State
of New York, et al., appellants, v. James Royster et al. The motion for
appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that James J. Mc-
Donough, Esquire, and Matthew Muraskin, Esquire, of Mineola, New
York, be, and they are hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the
appellees in this case.

TUESDAY, MAY 30, 1972
623
No. 71-1511. David L. Norvell, Attorney General of the State of
New Mexico, appellant, v. A. L. Happy Apodaca; and
No. 71-1512. Terry Brown et al., petitioners, v. A. L. Happy
Apodaca et al. The motions to expedite consideration are denied.
No. 71–1531. Joseph M. Nolan, petitioner, v. The Judicial Council
of the Third Circuit of the United States, et al. The application for
a stay presented to Mr. Justice White, and by him referred to the
Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration
or decision of this application.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 71-1119. Indiana Employment Security Division et al., appel-
lants, v. Essie D. Burney. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Indiana. In this case probable
jurisdiction noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 71-1178. Gulf States Utilities Company, petitioner, v. Federal
Power Commission et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit granted.
No. 71-1192. Donald Goldstein, Ruth Koven and Donald Koven,
petitioners, v. California. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Appel-
late Department of the Superior Court of California, County of Los
Angeles, granted.
No. 71–229. United States, petitioner, v. Antonio Dionisio; and
No. 71-850. United States, petitioner, v. In re September 1971
Grand Jury, Richard J. Mara aka Richard J. Marasovich. Petitions
for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit granted and cases to be argued in tandem.
No. 71-1371. Pedro J. Rosario et al., petitioners, v. Nelson Rocke-
feller, Governor of the State of New York, et al. Motion of Lawyers for
McGovern for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit granted. Motion for summary reversal or, in the alter-
native, for expedited consideration on the merits denied. Mr. Justice
Stewart would expedite consideration on the merits. Application for
stay, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him referred to the
Court, denied. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant the stay.
No. 71-6042. Ronald Dale Wardius, petitioner, v. Oregon. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Oregon granted.

TUESDAY, MAY 30, 1972
629
No. 71-6106. Robert Valentine, petitioner, v. Louisiana. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana denied, it
appearing that the judgment rests upon an adequate state ground.
Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 71-1291. Stephen S. Chandler, petitioner, v. Frank J. Battisti,
Chief Judge, United States District Court for the Northern District
of Ohio. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of mandamus and/or
prohibition denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this motion.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 71-1208. Jack Rose, petitioner, v. Doris Rose et al.;
No. 71-5852. William F. Coopersmith, petitioner, v. Town of
Grand Lake et al.; and
No. 71-6123. Garnet Stinson, petitioner, v. Frank A. Eyman, War-
den. Petitions for rehearing denied.
No. 71-605. Aaron Henry et al., petitioners, v. Claiborne Hard-
ware Company et al. Motion to dispense with printing petition granted.
Petition for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion
and petition.
No. 71-5164. F. Thomas Freeman, petitioner, v. Ray H. Page,
Warden. Motion for leave to file petition for rehearing denied.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until Wednesday, June 7,
1972.

OPINIONS
No. 70-5064. Ruth J. Jefferson et al., appellants, v. Burton G.
Hackney et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Texas. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan concurs. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Mar-
shall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins and Mr. Justice Stewart
joins as to Part I only.
No. 70-21. Socialist Labor Party et al., appellants, v. John J. Gilli-
gan, Governor of the State of Ohio, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio. Appeal dis-
missed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Mar-
shall join.
No. 71-315. Deepsouth Packing Co., Inc., petitioner, v. The Lai-
tram Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr.
Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 71-41. International Union of Operating Engineers, Local 150,
AFL-CIO, petitioner, v. Flair Builders, Inc. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.

TUESDAY, MAY 30, 1972
637
No. 71-422. Lake Carriers' Association et al., appellants, v.
Ralph A. MacMullan et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Eastern District of Michigan. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Michigan with directions to retain jurisdic-
tion pending institution by appellants of appropriate proceedings
in Michigan courts. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Statement
by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in the result, with whom
Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.
ORDER
The orders heretofore entered today summarily disposing of the
cases below listed are revoked and the following substituted
therefor:
No. 70–303. United States, petitioner. v. Jack Korman and
Robert W. Likas. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit; and
No. 71-775. United States, petitioner, v. Lee Cropper. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Petitions for writs of ceriorari ganted. Judg-
ments reversed. Kastigar v. United States, 406 U. S.
(1972).
No. 71-377. Albert Elias, Superintendent, Yardville Youth Re-
ception and Correction Center, petitioner, v. Gerardo Catena.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment reversed. Zicarelli v. New Jersey State Com-
mission of Invesigation, 406 U. S.
(1972). Mr. Justice
Douglas Dissents.
Adjourned until Wednesday, June 7, 1972, at 10 o'clock.
☑

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 7, 1972
638
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said :
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 69-5041. Theodore E. Boutte, appellant, v. Louisiana. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas dissents.
No. 71-1070. Jack Keegan, appellant, v. Illinois. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 71-1104. Northern Natural Gas Company, appellant, v. Jean
Williams et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Kansas. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
is denied.
No. 71-1301. Robert L. Brewster, appellant, v. Lewis J. Charles
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 71-1209. United Transportation Union et al., appellants, v.
United States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Columbia. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas
dissents from the affirmance. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 71-1321. Edward V. Hanrahan, appellant, v. Emil Caliendo
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
480-278-72– -127

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 7, 1972
639
No. 71-1339. Republic National Bank of Dallas et al., appellants,
v. Demetrio P. Rodriguez et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Western District of Texas. The appeal is dismissed.
Treating the jurisdictional statement in this case as a motion for leave
to file a brief, as amici curiae on behalf of the appellants in No. 71–1332,
the motion for leave to file brief is granted.
No. 71-5647. Daisy Goodwin et al., appellants, v. George K. Wy-
man et al. Appeal from the United States District for the Southern
District of New York. Judgment affirmed. Jefferson v. Hackney,
406 U.S.- (1972). Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from the affirmance.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION

et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Cali-
fornia Motion of the respondents for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgement va-
cated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of California for fur-
ther consideration in light of Jefferson v. Hackney, 406 U.S.·
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
-
(1972).
No. A-1151. Joel Donald Dreer, applicant, v. United States. The
application for recall of the mandate and for reinstatement of bail,
presented to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him referred to the Court, is
denied.
No. 71–507. Wilfred Keyes et al., petitioners, v. School District
No. 1, Denver, Colorado, et al. The motion of the American Civil Liber-
ties Union et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted. Mr.
Justice White took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 71-1193. United States, appellant, v. Travis Paul Enmons
et al. The motion to dispense with printing the appendix and to hear
the case on the original record is granted.
No. 71-1510. David Ross, Administrative Judge of the Criminal
Court of the City of New York, et al., petitioners, v. Stephen Radich.
The motion to expedite consideration of the petition is denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 71-1513. Anthony Joseph Russo, Jr., petitioner, v. Wm. Matt-
hew Byrne, Jr., United States District Judge for the Central District
of California. The motion to expedite consideration of the petition is
denied.

640
No. 71-6278. Condrado Almeida-Sanchez, petitioner, v. United
States. The motion for the appointment of counsel is granted, and it is
ordered that James A. Chanoux, Esquire, of San Diego, California, a
member of the Bar of this Court be, and he is hereby, appointed to
serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.

OPINIONS
No. 71–227. United States et al, appellants, v. Allegheny-Ludlum
Steel Corporation et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Western District of Pennsylvania. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the Western
District of Pennsylvania for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 70–295. First National City Bank, petitioner, v. Banco Na-
cional de Cuba. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 7, 1972
653
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the judgment of this Court. Mr. Justice Rehnquist an-
nounced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion in which
Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice White join. Mr. Justice
Douglas reverses judgment below solely on National City Bank of New
York v. Republic of China, 348 U.S. 356. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas concurring in the result. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell con-
curring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
with whom Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Blackmun join.
No. 71-573. Melvin Laird, Secretary of Defense, et al., petitioners,
v. Jim Nick Nelms, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-5009. Theon Jackson, petitioner, v. Indiana. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Indiana. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Indiana for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70–314. Brunette Machine Works, Ltd., petitioner, v. Kockum
Industries, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall.
No. 70–5061. Thomas Kirby, etc., petitioner, v. Illinois. On writ
of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. Judg-
ment affirmed. Mr. Justice Stewart announced the judgment of the
Court and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger,
Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Concurring
statement by Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Powell concurs in
the result. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan in which Mr.
Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting statement
by Mr. Justice White.
No. 71-5313. Donald L. Brooks, petitioner, v. Tennessee. On writ
of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Tennessee Judg
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals
of Tennessee for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr. Justice Stewart
joins part II of the opinion and in the judgment of this Court. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger in which Mr. Justice
EASTERN Division

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 7, 1972
654
Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice
Blackmun join.
No. 71-1016. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Louisiana
Power & Light Company et al.; and
No. 71-1040. United Gas Pipe Line Company et al., petitioners, ?.
Louisiana Power & Light Company et al. On writs of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 71-506. United States et al., petitioners, v. Midwest Video
Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conform-
ity with the judgment of this Court. Mr. Justice Brennan announced
the judgment of this Court and delivered an opinion in which Mr.
Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in the result. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Stewart,
Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 70-250. Robert B. Carleson et al., appellants, v. Nancy Remil-
lard, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of California. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas. Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
No. 68-5027. Earnest James Aikens, Jr., petitioner, v. California.
On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California. Writ of
certiorari dismissed as moot. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr.
Chief Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Monday, June 12, 1972, at 10 o'clock.

1
MONDAY, JUNE 12, 1972
655
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 71–784. Dorothy Taylor et al., petitioners, v. John J. Mc-
Keithen, Governor of Louisiana, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Blackmun con-
curs in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist
with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Powell join.
No. 71-1180. John Thomas Flower, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam. Mr. Justice Blackmun dissents. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.
No. 71-6425. Ivan V., petitioner, v. City of New York. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division of the Supreme
Court of New York, First Judicial Department. Motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Appellate Division of
the Supreme Court of New York, First Judicial Department, for fur-
ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion per curiam. Mr. Chief Justice Burger took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
_
No. 71-1396. John C. Danforth, Attorney General of Missouri,
et al., appellants, v. Del C. Preisler et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Western District of Missouri. Judgment affirmed.
480-278-72-130

MONDAY, JUNE 12, 1972
656
No. 71-5443. Larry E. Harvey, appellant, v. Tennessee. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Eastern Division. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma paperis granted. Judgment reversed. Brooks
v. Tennessee, 406 U.S. (1972).
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-5024. David J. Farrell, petitioner, v. William J. Stovall
et al. One petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Wisconsin. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin for further consideration in light
of Humphrey v. Cady, 405 U.S. 504 (1972) and Jackson v. Indiana,
406 U.S.- (1972).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 70-105. Edward V. Hanrahan, State's Attorney of Cook
County, Illinois, appellant, v. Jane Doe and Sally Roe, etc., et al.;
and
No. 70-106. Bart Heffernan, Guardian ad litem, appellant, v. Jane
Doe and Sally Roe et al. The application of appellees for vacation of
stay, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him referred to the
Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would vacate the stay.
No. 71–703. United States, appellant, v. First National Bancor-
poration, Inc., et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for additional
time for oral argument is granted and 15 additional minutes allotted
for that purpose. Counsel for the appelles also alloted 15 additional
minutes for oral argument. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 71–1345. James B. Crismon, petitioner, v. United States. The
petitioner's second application for bail pending decision on his petition
for certiorari, presented to Mr. Justice Blackmun and by him referred
to the Court, is denied.
No. 71–1476. J. Brian Gaffney, appellant, v. Theodore R. Cum-
mings et al. The application for stay of judgment of the United
States District Court for the District of Connecticut, presented to Mr.
Justice Marshall and by him referred to the Court, is granted. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Stewart would
deny the application.

tion noted.

Court of Massachusetts denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion
chat certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-1215. Gary Richard Tigerman, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-1224. Alfred Edward McGee, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion
that certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-1258. Lawrence Demangone, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-1271. Don Schneider, etc., petitioner, v. Melvin R. Laird,
Secretary of Defense, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.

663
No. 71-1334. Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, peti-
tioner, v. Victor Desny. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court
of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District, denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 71–1341. Michael Louis Behr et al., petitioners, v. California.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Department of the
Superior Court of California, County of Los Angeles, denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.

erton Coal Company and Davison Fuel and Dock Company. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.

Examinations and Admissions of the Supreme Court of Arizona.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.

States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.

for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.

tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that
certiorari should be granted.

Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Carolina.
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be
granted.

orari should be granted.

for the Seventh Circuit denied.

MONDAY, JUNE 12, 1972
664
No. 71-1365. Ranger Insurance Company, petitioner, v. Miriam
G. Culberson Executrix, et al. Motion of respondent for leave to pro-

United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.

Hart. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 71-1462. Solo Cup Company, petitioner, v. Illinois Tool
Works, Inc. Motion of Sweetheart Plastics, Inc., for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 71-6129. Robert McDonnell, petitioner, v. Charles L. Wolff,
Jr., Warden, et al.; and
No. 71-6479. Theophilus C. Williams, petitioner, v. California.
Motions for leave to file petitions for writs of habeas corpus denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 71-6362. Lynward James Daye, Jr., et al., petitioners, v. John
D. Larkins, Judge, et al.; and
No. 71–6480. Daniel Tilli, petitioner, v. John M. Davis et al. Mo-
tions for leave to file petitions for writs of mandamus denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 70-78. Affiliated Ute Citizens of the State of Utah et al., pe-
titioners, v. United States et al.; and
No. 71-962. William Donald Kelley et al., petitioners, v. Texas
State Board of Medical Examiners. Petitions for rehearing denied.

MONDAY, JUNE 12, 1972
OPINIONS
672
No. 70-283. Frederick E. Adams, Warden, petitioner, v. Robert
Williams. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Marshall
joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins.
No. 70-75. Moose Lodge No. 107, appellant, v. K. Leroy Irvis et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle District.
of Pennsylvania. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania with in-
structions to enter a decree in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins.
No. 71-11. James R. James, Judicial Administrator, et al., appel-
lants, v. David E. Strange. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Kansas. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell.
No. 71-404. Lewis Colten, appellant, v. Kentucky. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of Kentucky. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White. Dissenting; opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 70-5039. Margarita Fuentes et al., appellants, v. Robert L.
Shevin, Attorney General of Florida, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Southern District of Florida; and
No. 70-5138. Paul Parham et al., appellants, v. Americo V. Cor-
tese et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Pennsylvania. Judgments vacated and cases remanded to
the respective United States District Courts for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr.
Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Blackmun join. Mr. Justice
Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or
decision of these cases.
No. 70-5015. Jon Richard Argersinger, petitioner, v. Raymond
Hamlin, Sheriff, Leon County, Florida. On writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Florida. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Supreme Court of Florida for further consideration not incon-

MONDAY, JUNE 12, 1972
673
sistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in the result. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Douglas and Mr. Justice Stewart join. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell
with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins concurring in the result.
No. 71-322. M/S Bremen and Unterweser Reederei, GMBH, pe-
titioners, v. Zapata Off-Shore Company. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Monday, June 19, 1972, at 10 o'clock.
☑

MONDAY, JUNE 19, 1972
674
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 71-1309. Dennis Turner, petitioner, v. Arkansas. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arkansas. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed, and case remanded for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion per curiam. Concurring statement by Mr. Justice Blackmun
with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joints. The Chief Justice, rather
than taking summary action would hear oral argument and give the
matter plenary consideration.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-1085. California, appellant, v. Clifford Ellis Kaplan. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of California. Motion of appellee for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. The appeal is dismissed,
it appearing that the judgment below rests upon an adequate state
ground.
No. 71-1400. United Air Lines, Inc., appellant, v. G. W. Porter-
field, Tax Commissioner of Ohio. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction
should be noted. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this appeal.
No. 71-1435. The State Department of Health and Rehabilitative
Services, et al., appellants, v. Antonio Zarate, etc., et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida.
Motion of appellees Herman and Pola Sheydwasser for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice
White is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be noted.
480-278-72—133

MONDAY, JUNE 19, 1972
675
No. 71-1477. Robert S. Dickens et ux., appellants, v. Penelope
Ernesto et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should
be noted.
No. 71-5400. Paul Ronnie Hickman, appellant, v. Virginia. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jursidiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas is of the opinion that probable jurisdiction should be
noted.
No. 71-5723. William K. McAllister, appellant, v. Virginia. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. Motion of appellant for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Virginia for further consideration
in light of Argersinger v. Hamlin, Sheriff, 407 U.S. — (1972). Mr.
Justice Douglas would reverse judgment of lower court.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
1
No. 70-5052. Donald Kammerer, petitioner, v. Washington et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Washing-
ton. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Supreme Court of Washington for further consideration in light
of Argersinger v. Hamlin, Sheriff, 407 U.S. — (1972).
-
No. 70-5053. Danny Eugene Fox, petitioner, v. City of Bellevue
et al. On petititon for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wash-
ington. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Supreme Court of Washington for further consideration in light
of Argersinger v. Hamlin, Sheriff, 407 U.S. — (1972).
-
-
No. 71-5722. William Wright, petitioner, v. Town of Wood. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of South Dakota for further consideration in light of
Argersigner v. Hamlin, Sheriff, 407 U.S (1972). Mr. Justice
Douglas would grant certiorari and reverse judgment of lower court.
No. 71-6445. George Llewellyn Jones, III, petitioner, v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Motiton for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. On the representa-
tion of the Solicitor General set forth in his memorandum for the

1.
MONDAY, JUNE 19, 1972
676
United States filed May 25, 1972, judgment vacated and case remanded
to Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of the position pres-
ently asserted by the Government.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 71-1592. Robert Shipley Auerbach et al., appellants, v. Mar-
vin Mandel, Governor of the State of Maryland, et al. The motion to
expedite is denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

Services, et al., petitioners, v. Eugene Rodriguez et al. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit granted.

v. John W. Flemings. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted and set for
oral argument with No. 71-6314.
No. 71-6314. James Roy Gosa, petitioner, v. J. A. Mayden, War-
den. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted and set for oral argument
with No. 71-1398.

Mr. Solictor General Griswold presented the Hon-
orable Richard G. Kleindienst, Attorney General of the
United States.
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Attorney General, the Court welcomes you to the
performance of the important duties which devolve upon
you as the chief law officer of the Government, and as an
officer of this Court. Your Commission will be recorded

MONDAY, JUNE 19, 1972
OPINIONS
687
No. 70–153. United States, petitioner, v. United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, Southern Division, et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Mr.
Chief Justice Burger concurs in the result. Concurring opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in
judgment. Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideraiton or
decision of this case.
No. 71-5445. Gerald Shadwick, appellant, v. City of Tampa. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Florida. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell.
No. 71-32. Curtis C. Flood, petitioner, v. Bowie K. Kuhn et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black-
mun. Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice White join in parts
II, III and IV of the opinion and in the judgment. Concurring state-
ment by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 71-5144. Edward Lee McNeil, petitioner, v. Director, Patux-
ent Institution. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Special Appeals
of Maryland. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Special Appeals of Maryland for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. The mandate shall issue forthwith.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
No. 70-27. Robert Mitchum, dba The Book Mart, appellant, v.
Clinton E. Foster, Prosecuting Attorney of Bay County, Florida, et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Florida. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Florida for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger with whom Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Black-
mun join. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.

MONDAY, JUNE 19, 1972
688
No. 40, Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, plaintiff, v.
State of New York et al. On bill of complaint. Decree recommended
by the Special Master adopted and entered, and the cause is re-
ferred to the Special Master for further proceedings and the filing of a
proposed supplemental decree with respect to the distribution of costs.
of the inquiry as to available addresses. Opinion by Mr. Justice Bren-
man. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Ni Antice
Engia Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 70–5276. Albert Delanor Murel et al., petitioners, v. Baltimore
City Criminal Court et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Writ dismissed as improv-
idently granted. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Adjourned until Thursday, June 22, 1972, at 10 o'clock.

THURSDAY, JUNE 22, 1972
689
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr.
Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
OPINIONS
No. 71-5255. Willie Mae Barker, petitioner, v. John W. Wingo,
Warden. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan joins.
No. 70-223. Central Hardware Company, petitioner, v. National
Labor Relations Board et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration
in light of the principles of NLRB v. Babcock & Wilcox, 351 U.S.
105 (1956). Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Brennan join.
No. 71-492. Lloyd Corporation, Ltd, petitioner, v. Donald M.
Tanner et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals with directions to vacate the injunction.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Stewart join.
No. 71-5078. Dean Rene Peters, petitioner, v. C. P. Kiff, Warden.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the judgment
of this Court. Mr. Justice Marshall announced the judgment and
delivered an opinion in which Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart join. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in the
judgment in which Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Powell
join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger with whom
Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 70-188. Pecola Annette Wright et al., petitioners, v. Council
of the City of Emporia et al. On writ of certiorari to the United.
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed

THURSDAY, JUNE 22, 1972
690
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger with whom

join.
No. 70-130. United States, petitioner, v. Scotland Neck City Board
of Education et al.; and
No. 70-187. Pattie Black Cotton et al., petitioners, v. Scotland
Neck City Board of Education et al. On writs of certiorari to the

reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger con-
curring in the result, with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 70-74. Pipefitters Local Union No. 562 et al., petitioners, v.
United States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment vacated as to petitioners
Callanan and Lawler and case remanded to the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Eastern District of Missouri with directions to
dismiss the indictment against them. Judgment reversed as to peti-
tions Local 562 and Seaton and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins. Mr. Justice Blackmun took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-5012. George William Milton, petitioner, v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Director, Florida Division of Corrections. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Douglas,
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
Adjourned until Monday, June 26, 1972, at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 71-5625. John R. Kois, petitioner, v. Wisconsin. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court
of Wisconsin for further consideration not inconsistent with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Stewart concurs in
the judgment. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 71-6497. Johnny Daniel Beecher, petitioner, v. Alabama. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama. Mo-
tion for leave to proceed in form pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Su-
preme Court of Alabama for further consideration not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 35, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of Maine et al.
The motion of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts for a preliminary
injunction is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.
No. 40, Original. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, plaintiff, v.
State of New York et al. It is ordered that the expenditures of John
F. Davis as Special Master in the amount of $626.54 be approved. It is
further ordered that the balance of advances made by the parties to
meet expenses in the amount of $1,373.46 be retained by the Special
Master and applied toward his compensation. It is further ordered
that the total compensation for the Special Master be fixed at Ten
Thousand and Five Hundred Dollars ($10,500) and that that amount,
less the balance of the money advanced for expenses, shall be paid to
him by Western Union out of the funds in its possession which are the
subject of this suit and that Western Union be given credit for that
amount divided pro rata among the parties who would otherwise be
entitled to the money under the opinion and decree of this Court.
No. 50, Original. State of Vermont, plaintiff v. State of New York
et al. It is ordered that Justice R. Ammi Cutter (Retired) be, and he
is hereby, appointed Special Master to conduct supplemental proceed-
ings in this case. The Special Master shall have authority to fix the
time and conditions for filing of additional pleadings and to direct
subsequent proceedings, and authority to summon witnesses, issue
subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be introduced and such as
he may deem it necessary to call for. The Master is directed to submit
such reports as he may deem appropriate.

MONDAY, JUNE 26, 1972
695
The Master shall be allowed his actual expenses. The allowances to
him, the compensation paid to his technical, stenographic, and clerical
assistants, the cost of printing his reports, and all other proper ex-
penses shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such
proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master becomes
vacant during the recess of the Court, the Chief Justice shall have
authority to make a new designation which shall have the same effect
as if originally made by the Court herein.
No. 54, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. States of Florida and
Texas. The motion to defer consideration is denied. The motion of the
State of Texas for the appointment of a Special Master is granted
and it is ordered that the Honorable Charles L. Powell, Senior Judge
of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wash-
ington, be, and he is hereby, appointed Special Master in this case.
The Special Master shall have authority to fix the time and condi-
tions for filing of additional pleadings and to direct subsequent pro-
ceedings, and authority to summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and
take such evidence as may be introduced and such as he may deem it
necessary to call for. The Master is directed to submit such reports as
he may deem appropriate.
The Master shall be allowed his actual expenses, the allowances to
him, the compensation paid to his technical, stenographic, and cleri-
cal assistants, the cost of printing his reports, and all other proper
expenses shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such
proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master becomes
vacant during the recess of the Court, the Chief Justice shall have
authority to make a new designation which shall have the same effect
as if originally made by the Court herein.

8mm. Film et al.

No. 71-1051. Paris Adult Theatre I, et al., petitioners, v. Lewis
R. Slaton, District Attorney, Atlanta Judicial Circuit, et al. Motion to
supplement petition and petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Georgia granted. The parties are requested to brief and argue
in addition to those questions presented in the petition the following
question:
"Whether the display of any sexually oriented films in a commercial
theatre, when surrounded by notice to the public of their nature and by
reasonable protection against exposure of the films to juveniles, is con-
stitutionally protected?"

Esquire, of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, a member of the Bar of this Court,
be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent
in this case.

Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Virginia
granted and the parties are requested to brief and argue in addition to

for commercial sale, when surrounded by notice to the public of their
nature and by reasonable protection against exposure of the maga-
zines to juveniles, is constitutionally protected?"

RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until, Thursday, June 29,
1972, upon which day it will adjourn for the term unless otherwise
ordered.
