MONDAY, JUNE 26, 1972
OPINIONS
711
No. 71–237. Vincent R. Mancusi, Warden petitioner, v. William
C. Stubbs. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall joined in Part II by Mr.
Justice Douglas.
No. 71-308. United States, petitioner, v. Marian A. Byrum, Execu-
trix under the last will and testament of Milliken C. Byrum. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Brennan
and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.
No. 71-452. Catherine J. Healy et al., petitioners, v. F. Don James
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist concurring in the result. Statement by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 70-87. Police Department of the City of Chicago et al., peti-
tioners, v. Earl D. Mosley. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist con-
cur in the result.
No. 70-5106. Richard Grayned, appellant, v. City of Rockford.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment affirmed in
part and reversed in part and case remanded to the Supreme Court of
Illinois for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice Blackmun
joins in the judgment and in part I of the opinion of this Court,
and concurs in the result as to Part II of the opinion. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas dissenting in part.
No. 71-110. David Gelbard and Sidney Parnas, petitioners, v.
United States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit; and
No. 71–263. United States, petitioner, v. Jogues Egan and Anne
Elizabeth Walsh. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment in No. 71-110 reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Judgment in No. 71–263 af-

MONDAY, JUNE 26, 1972
712
firmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice
Burger, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell join.
No. 71-288. Melvin R. Laird, Secretary of Defense, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Arlo Tatum et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion of
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas
with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall join.
No. 71-517. Elisha Combs, petitioner, v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals with directions that the case be sent back to the District Court
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Thursday, June 29, 1972, at 10 o'clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

OPINIONS
No. 71-16. Richard G. Kleindienst, Attorney General of the United
States, et al., appellants, v. Ernest Mandel et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of New York for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan
joins.
No. 70-31. Port of Portland et al., appellants, v. United States
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Oregon. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of Oregon with instructions to
remand case to the Interstate Commerce Commission for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 71–1017. Mike Gravel, United States Senator, petitioner, v.
United States; and
No. 11-1026. United States, petitioner, v. Mike Gravel, United
States Senator. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment vacated and cases remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White announced by
Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.

THURSDAY, JUNE 29, 1972
714
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stew-
art dissenting in part.
No. 70-85. Paul M. Branzburg, petitioner, v. John P. Hayes,
Judge, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of
Kentucky;
No. 70-94. In the Matter of Paul Pappas, petitioner. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts; and
No. 70-57. United States, petitioner, v. Earl Caldwell. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgments in Nos. 70-85 and 70-94 affirmed. Judgment in No. 70–57
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice White announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents in No.
70–57. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 71-162. The Board of Regents of State Colleges et al., peti-
tioners, v. David F. Roth, etc. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger in this case
and in No. 70-36, post. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Douglas joins in this case and dissenting in part in No. 70-36, post.
Mr. Justice Marshall dissents. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-36. Charles R. Perry et al., petitioners, v. Robert P. Sinder-
mann, etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in this case
and in No. 71–162, ante. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom
Mr. Justice Douglas joins dissenting in part in this case and dissenting
in No. 71-162, ante. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall dissenting in
part.
No. 69-5003. William Henry Furman, petitioner, v. Georgia. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia ;
No. 69-5030. Lucious Jackson, Jr., petitioner, v. Georgia. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia; and
No. 69-5031. Elmer Branch, petitioner, v. Texas. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. Judgments re-

THURSDAY, JUNE 29, 1972
715
versed insofar as they leave undisturbed the death sentences imposed,
and cases remanded to their respective courts for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam
announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissent-

Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Dis-

Blackmun, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr.
Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell join.
No. 69-5001. Lyman A. Moore, petitioner, v. Illinois. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment reversed insofar
as it imposes the death sentence, and case remanded to the Supreme
Court of Illinois for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell join, concurring in part and
dissenting in part.
No. 71-5103. John J. Morrissey and G. Donald Booher, peti-
tioners, v. Lou V. Brewer, Warden, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas dissenting
in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Mar-
shall joins concurring in the result.
No. 70-45. United States, appellant, v. Daniel B. Brewster. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the District of Colum-
bia. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Columbia for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr.
Justice Douglas joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with
whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan join.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."

THURSDAY, JUNE 29, 1972
OPINION PER CURIAM
716
No. 71-5446. John S. Stewart, appellant, v. Massachusetts. Appeal
from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. Motion for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment vacated insofar as
it leaves undisturbed the death penalty imposed, and case remanded
to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts for further pro-
ceedings. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 68-5012. Thomas Cornelius Howard, appellant, v. Nevada.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Nevada. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 68-5017. Willie Johnson and Edison Arthur Singleton, appel-
lants, v. Louisiana. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment
vacated insofar as it leaves undisturbed the death penalty imposed,
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Louisiana for further
proceedings. See Stewart v. Massachusetts, — U.S. (1972).
No. 69-5050. John E. Kerrigan, appellant, v. Palmer C. Scafati,
Superintendent, Massachusetts Correctional Institution. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment
vacated insofar as it leaves undisturbed the death penalty imposed,
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the District
of Massachusetts for further proceedings. See Stewart v. Massachu-
setts, U.S.— (1972).

_
No. 71-5073. Duane Pope, appellant, v. Nebraska. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Nebraska. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Judgment vacated insofar as it leaves undisturbed
the death penalty imposed, and case remanded for further proceedings.
See Stewart v. Massachusetts, — U.S. (1972). Mr. Justice
Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 70-210. Waldemar Ager Oyen et al., appellants, v. Washing-

further consideration in light of Police Department of the City of

No. 71–819. Robert S. Thomas et al., petitioners, v. Ruth Shirck;
and
No. 71-946. Ruth Shirck, petitioner, v. Robert S. Thomas et al. On
petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Petitions for writs of certiorari granted,
judgment vacated, and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further consideration in light of Board of Regents of State Colleges
v. Roth,
U.S.
(1972). Mr. Justice Douglas would affirm
judgment below.

tion of the City of New York. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further consideration in light of Perry v. Sindermann,
U.S.

wright, Director, Florida Division of Corrections. Motion for leave.

of habeas corpus as petition for certiorari to the Supreme Court of

No. 70-5020. Edward Williams, petitioner, v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Director, Florida Division of Adult Corrections. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Treating the petition for
writ of habeas corpus as a petition for certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated insofar as it leaves undisturbed the death penalty imposed,
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings.
See Stewart v. Massachusetts, U.S. ― (1972).

tioner, v. Ohio. Petition for rehearing granted. Judgment affirming)

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 71-1255. United States, petitioner, v. Charles J. Ash, Jr. The
motion for the appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered
that Sherman L. Cohn, Esquire, of Washington, D.C., a member of
the Bar of this Court, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as
counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 71-575. Linda Gomez, individually and as next friend of Zo-
raida Gomez, appellant v. Francisco Ocasio Perez. Joseph Jaworski,
Esquire, of Houston, Texas, a member of the Bar of this Court, is
invited to brief and argue this case, as amicus curiae, in support of
the judgment below.

No. 70–228. Warden, Maryland Penitentiary, petitioner, v. Wil-
liam Ralph; and
No. 70-5198. William Ralph, petitioner, v. Warden, Maryland
Penitentiary. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied.
No. 71-1284. New Jersey, petitioner, v. Euther Presha et al. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of New Jersey
denied.
No. 70-322. In the Matter of the Imprisonment of William B.
Warren, petitioner. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Superior
Court Division of the General Court of Justice of Caswell County,
North Carolina, denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari,
vacate judgment below and remand case for further consideration in
light of his dissenting opinion in Morrissey v. Brewer,
(1972).
U.S.
No. 70–141. T. Ellis Hodgin, petitioner, v. Thomas B. Noland,
City Manager, etc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 70-354. Jack Fooden, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Board of Gov-
ernors of State Colleges and Universities of Illinois. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-430. Ralph D. Crabtree, petitioner, v. Board of Education,
Wellston City School District, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the Supreme Court of Ohio denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the
opinion that certiorari should be granted.
No. 71-6259. Peter McEnteggart, petitioner, v. John M. Cataldo
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the First Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas is of the
opinion that certorari should be granted.
No. 71–249. Thomas Justin Orr, petitioner, v. Raymond E. Trinter
et al. Motion of the National Education Association for leave to file
a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of the Board of Education
of the City of Washington, C. H., Ohio, for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas is of the opinion that certiorari should be granted.

THURSDAY, JUNE 29, 1972
738
The Chief Justice announced the following order of the Court:
"All cases submitted and all business before the Court at this term
in readiness for disposition having been disposed of,
"It is ordered by this Court that all cases on the docket be, and they
are hereby, continued to the next term."
Adjourned to the time and place appointed by law.
